military_blank2 = | military_data2 = | military_blank3 = | military_data3 = | military_blank4 = | military_data4 = | military_blank5 = | military_data5 = }} '''Abbas Noyan''' ({{lang-prs|عباس نویان}}) is an ethnic [[Hazara people|Hazara]] politician in [[Afghanistan]] who served as a Member of Parliament to [[House of the People (Afghanistan)|Wolesi Jirga]], the lower house, representing the people of [[Kabul province]] from 2005 to 2010. In 2005, he ranked seventh among candidates from Kabul province, quickly rising to one of the most prominent and active representatives at the Wolesi Jirga. {{cite news|url=http://d8680609.u106.forthost.com/leadingCandidates.asp?ElectionID=1&ProvinceID=1&offset=0|title=Wolesi Jirga & Provincial Council Elections Afghanistan 2005 Elections|author=|accessdate=2012-03-07|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130102161525/http://d8680609.u106.forthost.com/leadingCandidates.asp?ElectionID=1&ProvinceID=1&offset=0|archive-date=2013-01-02|dead-url=yes|publisher=[[United Nations]]|year=2005|page=|quote=}} During his tenure, he advocated for women's rights, education for all, a responsive and accountable government, and a strong rule of law. Noyan has worked across ethnic and sectarian divides in representing his constituents, and sought to bridge those divides by establishing a multi-ethnic political party. {{cite news|url=http://www.nps.edu/programs/ccs/Docs/Executive%20Summaries/Kabul_Executive_Summary.pdf|title=Profile: KabulProvince|author=|accessdate=|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.nps.edu%2Fprograms%2Fccs%2FDocs%2FExecutive%2520Summaries%2FKabul_Executive_Summary.pdf&date=2010-06-15|archivedate=2010-06-15|deadurl=yes|publisher=[[Naval Postgraduate School]]|year=2005|page=|quote=}} == Early Life and Education == Abbas Noyan hails from [[Turkman Valley]] of [[Parwan province]] and grew up in Kabul. He was born in a politically active family; his father Haji Saleh Mohammad Khan was one of the elders of the [[Turkmun (Hazara tribe)|Turkmani Hazaras]] and served as a Member of Parliament during Dawood Shah's reign. Abbas Noyan became politically active while still in high school, fighting against systematic discrimination of minority groups and for a responsive and accountable government for all. For his peaceful political protests, he was briefly imprisoned, suspended from school, and dispatched to serve his mandatory military service in Asmar district of Kunar province, one of the most dangerous parts of the country. Abbas Noyan went on to studying civil engineering at Polytechnic Institute. His classmates included [[Ahmad Shah Masood]] and [[Gulbuddin Hekmatyar]]. == Family Life and Career == [[File:Abbas Noyan at campaign.jpg|thumb|left|Abbas Noyan at a campaign rally in Kabul in October 2018.]] [[File:Abbas Noyan in Kabul in 2018.jpg|thumb|Abbas Noyan, giving speech at a rally in Kabul in October 2018.]] [[File:Abbas Noyan at a rally.jpg|thumb|Abbas Noyan at a campaign rally for women in Kabul.]] At the time of Abbas's graduation from university, the country was becoming increasingly socially and politically unrestful. To suppress the population, the communist regime of [[Hafizullah Amin]] decreed the elimination and execution of any person with influence and prominence and who fought for human and political rights of the people. In 1978, Haji Saleh Mohammad Khan and his three sons were take away in the middle of the night by the secret police and executed. Abbas barely escaped capture. The family learned of the fate of Haji Saleh and his sons 35 years later including the place of their mass burial. Abbas Noyan became the sole provider for his extended family. He started his business and ran it in Russia, U.S., Japan, and the U.A.E. After establishing himself in business, he returned to his country in 2005 and ran for parliament. Abbas Noyan is identified as progressive and reformist. He represented the Kabul province in parliament, becoming one of the most vocal critics of widespread corruption. He advocated for women's rights and elimination of violence against women. After his term at the national assembly, he founded the [[Truth and Justice (Afghanistan)|Truth and Justice]] political party (also known as Rights and Justice) together with [[Hanif Atmar]], Ehsanullah Zia, [[Sima Samar]], Mohammad Sardar Roshan, and [[Hamidullah Farooqi]]. The party successfully supported [[Ashraf Ghani|Ashraf Ghani's]] bid to presidency in 2014. == Personal == A life-long supporter of education, he sits on the board of [http://marefat.edu.af/en/ Marefat High School]. Noyan has three sons and two daughters. He lives in Kabul with his family. == See also == * [[Truth and Justice (Afghanistan)|Truth and Justice]] * [[List of Hazara people]] == References == {{Reflist}} {{Commons category}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Noyan, Abbas}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1949 births]] [[Category:Hazara people]] [[Category:Hazara politicians]] [[Category:Afghan engineers]] [[Category:Members of the House of the People (Afghanistan)]]

{{Orphan|date=June 2013}} {{Infobox military person | honorific_prefix = | name = Abbas Raza | honorific_suffix = | image = Vice Admiral Abbas Raza.JPG | image_upright = | alt = | caption = V-Adm. Abbas Raza addressing a press conference during multinational naval exercise AMAN 2011 | native_name = | native_name_lang = | birth_name = Abbas Raza | other_name = | nickname = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1955|05|16}} | birth_place = [[Lahore]], [[Punjab, Pakistan|Punjab]], [[Pakistan]] | death_date = | death_place = | placeofburial_label = | placeofburial = | placeofburial_coordinates = | allegiance = {{PAK}} | branch = [[File:Naval Jack of Pakistan.svg|20px]] [[Pakistan Navy]] | serviceyears = 1973–2012 | serviceyears_label = | rank = [[File:Insignia Vice Admiral Pakistan Navy.gif|10px]][[File:US-O9 insignia.svg|30px]][[Vice-Admiral]] | rank_label = | servicenumber = | unit =[[Pakistan Navy#Branches|Naval Operations Branch]] | commands =[[Pakistan Navy#Commands|Commander Pakistan Fleet]]

[[File:Sword of Honour @ Royal Military College of Canada.jpg|25px]][[Sword of Honour (Pakistan)|Sword of Honour]] | memorials = | spouse = | children = | relations = | laterwork = [[Managing Director|Director]] of [[Private military company|PMC]], the Bahria Security and Systems.{{cite web |title=Bahria Security Systems & Services |url=http://www.bahriasecurity.com/bahriafoundation/ |website=www.bahriasecurity.com |publisher=Bahria Security Systems & Services |accessdate=3 August 2018}} | signature = | signature_size = | signature_alt = | website = | module = }} [[Vice-Admiral]] '''Abbas Raza''' ([[Urdu]]:عباس رضا ;b. 16 May 1955),{{small|[[Hilal-i-Imtiaz|HI(m)]], [[Sitara-e-Imtiaz|SI (m)]], [[Tamgha-e-Imtiaz|TI(m)]]}}, is a retired [[Three-star rank|three-star]] rank [[Pak Bahria|admiral]] in the [[Pakistan Navy]] who served as the senior [[Pakistan Navy#Branches|fleet commander]] in 2010 until retiring in 2012.{{cite news |last1=Newspaper |first1=From the |title=New fleet commander |url=https://www.dawn.com/news/587217 |accessdate=3 August 2018 |work=DAWN.COM |agency=Dawn Newspaper |publisher=Dawn Newspaper |date=30 November 2010}}{{cite web |title=Vice Adm. Abbas Raza |url=https://petarians.net/vice-adm-abbas-raza/ |website=petarians.net |publisher=The Petarian Association |accessdate=3 August 2018 |language=en |format=tml |date=25 November 2012}} == Biography == Abbas Raza was born in 16 May 1955 in [[Lahore]], [[Punjab, Pakistan|Punjab]] in [[Pakistan]] where he secured his [[Matriculation in Pakistan|matriculation]], and joined the [[Pakistan Navy]] in June 1973.{{cite web |last1=et.a. |first1=staff |title=Vice Adm. Abbas Raza |url=http://www.petaro.org/staff-adjutants/adj-abbasraza.htm |website=www.petaro.org |publisher=Petaro |accessdate=3 August 2018}} He was directed to attend the [[Pakistan Naval Academy]] in [[Karachi]], and [[Passing out (military)|passed out]] with [[Military communications|communications]] with top of his class when he was conferred with coveted with the [[Sword of Honour (Pakistan)|Sword of Honor]] in 1975. He was qualified as the [[Surface warfare insignia|surface officer]] and served in the [[List of active Pakistan Navy ships|Surface Command]] of the Navy.{{cite news |last1=Newspaper |first1=From the |title=New Comkar |url=https://www.dawn.com/news/670591 |accessdate=3 August 2018 |work=DAWN.COM |agency=Dawn Newspaper |publisher=Dawn Newspaper |date=1 November 2011}} He gained [[Commissioned officer|commissioned]] in the [[Pakistan Navy#Branches|Naval Operations Branch]] as [[Sub lieutenant|Sub-Lieutenant]], and was later sent to attend and complete the [[Staff (military)|staff course]] at the [[Royal Naval Staff College]] in [[Greenwich]] in [[England]].{{cite news |last1=From the Newspaper |first1=staff |title=Promotion: Abbas takes charge as new commander {{!}} The Express Tribune |url=https://tribune.com.pk/story/286396/promotion-abbas-takes-charge-as-new-commander/ |accessdate=3 August 2018 |work=The Express Tribune |agency=The Express Tribune |publisher=The Express Tribune |date=2 November 2011}} He later went to attend the [[National Defence University, Islamabad|National Defence University]] (NDU) in [[Islamabad]] and graduated with [[Master of Science|MSc]] in [[Defence studies]].{{cite news |title=Abbas Raza promoted as rear admiral |url=https://www.dawn.com/news/228144 |accessdate=3 August 2018 |work=DAWN.COM |agency=Dawn Newspaper |publisher=Dawn Newspaper |date=16 January 2007}} As [[Commander (rank)|Commander]], he commanded the boat squadron, and held the commands of the [[PNS Badr (1994)|PNS ''Badr'']] and [[PNS Tippu Sultan (1994)|''Tippu Sultan'']] as [[captain (naval)|Captain]] in 1990s. In 2003, [[Captain (naval)|Capt.]] Raza was posted at the [[Diplomatic missions of Pakistan|Pakistan Embassy in Muscat]] in [[Oman]] as a [[Defense Attaché System|defence attaché]].{{rp|514}}{{cite book |last1=Jane |first1=Frederick Thomas |title=Jane's Fighting Ships |date=2003 |publisher=S. Low, Marston & Company |isbn=9780710625465 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rsYqAQAAMAAJ&q=Abbas+Raza+captain+attache&dq=Abbas+Raza+captain+attache&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi-wMTKptDcAhXGg1QKHdyACMIQ6wEIKDAA |accessdate=3 August 2018 |language=en}} Capt. Raza also briefly tenured at the [[List of diplomatic missions of Pakistan|Pakistan Embassy in Paris]] as an [[air attaché]] to [[French Air Force]]. Upon returning to Pakistan, [[Commodore (rank)|Cdre.]] Abbas Raza was appointed to command the [[Pakistan Navy#Commands|9th Auxiliary Squadron]], and briefly tenured as a military secretary to the office of the [[Chief of Naval Staff (Pakistan)|chief of naval staff]] at the [[NHQ (Pakistan Navy)|Navy NHQ]] in [[Islamabad]] as two-star and three-star rank appointments.{{cite news |title=Vice Admiral Abbas takes over as PN Karachi commander |url=https://www.pakistantoday.com.pk/2011/11/02/vice-admiral-abbas-takes-over-as-pn-karachi-commander/ |accessdate=3 August 2018 |work=www.pakistantoday.com.pk |date=3 November 2012}} [[Rear-Admiral]] Raza's other appointment at the [[NHQ (Pakistan Navy)|Navy NHQ]] also included his role as [[Deputy Chief of Naval Staff|DCNS (Projects)]], [[Deputy Chief of Naval Staff|DNCS (Operations)]] as well as being appointed as the [[Director-General]] of the [[Joint warfare|Joint Warfare and Training]] (DG Joint Trig.) at the [[JS HQ (Pakistan)|Joint Staff HQ]] in [[Rawalpindi]]. In 2010, [[Vice-Admiral]] Raza was took over the command of the [[Pakistan Navy#Commands|Pakistan Fleet]] as its senior [[Fleet Commander|fleet commander]], and later directed to command the [[Karachi coast]] as its field commander, [[Pakistan Navy#Commands|COMKAR]], and was responsible for naval units stationed in Karachi in 2011. In 2011, [[Vice-Admiral|V-Adm.]] Raza faced severe criticism from [[Pakistani media|news media]] pundits of failing to prevent [[PNS Mehran Operation|terrorist attack on naval installations]], and reportedly was not investigated in this incident by the Naval Intelligence and the Navy's crime branch.{{cite news |title=Controversy surrounds appointment of next Pakistan Naval Chief |url=http://spyeyesnews.blogspot.com/2011/09/controversy-surrounds-appointment-of.html |accessdate=3 August 2018 |date=27 September 2011}} In 2011, [[Vice-Admiral|V-Adm.]] Raza was among the four senior admirals who were in the race for the promotion to be promoted as a [[Four star admiral|four-star admiral]] in the Navy, included with seniority:{{cite news |last1=our staff reporter |first1=The Nation |title=4 names forwarded for new naval chief |url=https://nation.com.pk/28-Sep-2011/4-names-forwarded-for-new-naval-chief |accessdate=3 August 2018 |work=The Nation |agency=The Nation |date=28 September 2011}} **[[Vice-Admiral]] [[Asif Sandila]]., [[Chief of Staff of the Pakistan Navy|Vice-Chief of Naval Staff]] (VCNS) at the [[NHQ (Pakistan Navy)|Navy NHQ]] in Islamabad. **[[Vice-Admiral]] [[Tanveer Faiz]].{{cite news |last1=Staff writer |first1=et.al. |title=Asif Sandila made Naval Chief |url=https://fp.brecorder.com/2011/10/201110061238576/ |accessdate=5 August 2018 |agency=Business recorder |publisher=Business recorder |date=6 October 2011}} [[Deputy Chief of Naval Staff|DCNS (Projects)]] at the [[NHQ (Pakistan Navy)|Navy NHQ]] in Islamabad. **Vice-Admiral Abbas Raza. Senior commander in Karachi coast as [[Pakistan Navy#Command|Commander Karachi]] (COMKAR) **Vice-Admiral [[Tayyab Ali Dogar|T. A. Dogar]]. Senior [[Fleet Commander|fleet commander]] of the [[Pakistan Navy#Commands|Pakistan Fleet]] (COMPAK) On 6 October 2011, [[President of Pakistan|President]] [[Asif Ali Zardari]] eventually promoted Vice-Admiral [[Asif Sandila]], the senior most admiral, to the four-star rank position while all remaining admirals decided to serve on their respected commands until their retirements were confirmed.{{cite news |title=Admiral Sandila appointed naval chief |url=https://www.thenews.com.pk/archive/print/617116-admiral-sandila-appointed-naval-chief |accessdate=3 August 2018 |language=en}} In 2012, Vice-Admiral Raza retired from his military service, and eventually joining the Bahria Security System, the [[private military company]] specializing in escort and security, as its [[Managing Director]]. ==See also== *[[Pakistan Navy]] ==References== ==External links== *[http://dailymailnews.com/1110/30/Sindh/index.php?id=2 Source 1] *[http://timesofpakistan.pk/pakistan/2010-11-30/vice-admiral-abbas-takes-over-command-of-navel-fleet/14682/ Vice-Admiral Abbas takes over the Command of Fleet] {{DEFAULTSORT:Raza, Abbas}} [[Category:1955 births]] [[Category:Punjabi people]] [[Category:People from Lahore]] [[Category:Pakistan Naval Academy alumni]] [[Category:Graduates of the Royal Naval College, Greenwich]] [[Category:National Defence University, Pakistan alumni]] [[Category:Pakistan Navy admirals]] [[Category:Pakistani corporate directors]] [[Category:People working in public safety]] [[Category:Living people]]

{{BLP sources|date=August 2015}} {{orphan|date=May 2010}}
'''Abdelkrim Badjadja''' (born March 26, 1945 in [[Constantine, Algeria]]) is an [[Algeria]]n [[archivist]] and [[historian]]. He has contributed greatly to the development of the [[National Archives of Algeria]] (Archives Nationales d'Algerie) and the preservation and dissemination of Algerian history. He published several works on the [[history of Algeria]] and the archival profession in [[Arabic language|Arabic]] and [[French language|French]].
==Education== Badjadja attended the [[Université Constantine 1|University of Constantine]], Algeria where he studied [[history]] and [[geography]]. He received his license in 1972 and his DEA in 1974.
==Career== Badjadja served as the Director of the Archive Department of Constantine from 1974–1991, and then Director of the [[National Library of Algeria]] from 1991–1992. He was the Director General of the National Archives of Algeria (Archives Nationales d'Algerie) from 1992–2001. He currently serves as the Consulting Archivist at the Information and Research Center, at the Presidency in [[Abu Dhabi]], [[United Arab Emirates]]. He was also the director of the Archives de Wilaya de Constantine in [[Constantine, Algeria]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Prochaska |first=David |date=2004 |title=Making Algeria French: Colonialism in Bône, 1870–1920 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=aB2FdDy8xjEC&pg=PR18&dq=Abdelkarim+Badjadja&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CDsQ6AEwB2oVChMI9IHDz5WvxwIVzfqACh2d0QDD#v=onepage&q=Abdelkarim%20Badjadja&f=false |publisher=[[Cambridge University Press]] |page=1 |isbn=0521531284 |access-date=August 16, 2015}}</ref>
From November 1986 to March 1987, he was placed under town arrest restrictions but no official reasons were ever given.<ref> {{cite book |last=de Baets |first=Antoon |date=2002 |title=Censorship of Historical Thought: A World Guide, 1945–2000 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4DlMSrtOGLIC&pg=PA42&dq=Abdelkarim+Badjadja&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CCwQ6AEwBGoVChMI9IHDz5WvxwIVzfqACh2d0QDD#v=onepage&q=Abdelkarim%20Badjadja&f=false |publisher=[[Greenwood Publishing Group]] |page=42 |isbn=0313311935 |access-date=August 16, 2015}}</ref>
==Selected bibliography== * "The Application of Senatus Consulte (1863-1887) in Constantine," ''National Archives'' 3, 1975 * "The Political Life in Constantine (1935-1940) Using the Archives of North African Liaison Services in the Wilaya of Constantine," ''National Archives'' 6, 1977 * "Finding Methods in Archives Centre," ''CIRTA Magazine'' 1, 1979 * "The Andalusian Music, History and Theory," ''The Roch 3'' 1985 * ''Investigation Over the Standard of Life of the Moslem Population in Constantine in 1936,'' 1989 * "The Occupation of Expert in Archives Administration as a Liberal Profession," ''Arab Archives Magazine'' 15, 1990 * ''Maps of the Ancient Tribes in Eastern Algeria, 1863–1887,'' 1990 * "The Struggle of Constantine, 1836–1837," ''Quire of Tunsis'' 157–158, 1991 * "Moslem Registry Office in Constantine in 1256 H. (1840–41)," ''Madjallat El-Tarikh'' 25, 1992 * "Italian Associations in Eastern Algeria from 1906 to 1939," ''Mograbin History Magazine'' 67, 1992 * "The History of the Ancient Town of Constantine," ''Madjallat El-Tarikh'' 25, 1992 * "Administrative Archives Management, Poor Basic Structure Coping with Huge Quantity of Useless Papers," ''Arab Archives Magazine'' 16, 1992 * "Three Documents over Maritime Relationship between Algeria and Villefranche (Comite de Nice) in XVIIth and XVIIIth Centuries," ''Mograbin History Magazine'' 67–68, 1992 * "The Building Up and Promoting of Archives Centres," ''Arab Archives Magazine'' 17, 1997
==References== {{Reflist}} * International biographical directory of national archivists, documentalists, and librarians / edited by Jeffrey M. White, Todd J Kosmerick, Laurie Scrivener ; compiled by Susan Houck. 2nd ed. Lanham, Md. : Scarecrow Press, 2000. * International Counsel of Archives member directory: [https://web.archive.org/web/20090528023848/http://membres.lycos.fr/badjadja/]
== External links == * http://membres.lycos.fr/badjadja ({{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090528023848/http://membres.lycos.fr/badjadja/ |date=May 28, 2009 }})
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Badjadja, Abdelkarim}} [[Category:1945 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Archivists]] [[Category:Algerian people]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox saint |name = [[Canonization|Saint]]
Angelus
[[Carmelites|O.Carm.]] |birth_date = 1185 |death_date = 5 May 1220 (aged 35) |feast_day = 5 May |venerated_in = [[Roman Catholic Church]] |image = saintangelus.jpg |imagesize = 200px |caption = Portrait. |birth_place = [[Jerusalem]], [[Byzantine Empire]] |death_place = [[Licata]], [[Kingdom of Sicily]] |titles = Priest; Martyr |beatified_date = |beatified_place = |beatified_by = |canonized_date = {{circa}} 1459 |canonized_place = [[Rome]], [[Papal States]] |canonized_by = [[Pope Pius II]] |attributes = {{unbulleted list|[[Religious habit|Carmelite habit]]|Sword through chest|Book|Palm|Three crowns|Lilies|Roses}} |patronage = {{unbulleted list|[[Palermo]]|Licata|[[Sant'Angelo Muxaro]]}} |major_shrine = Santa Maria del Carmine |suppressed_date = |issues = |prayer = |prayer_attrib = }} [[Canonization|Saint]] '''Angelus''' ({{lang-it|Sant'Angelo}}; 1185 – 5 May 1220) was a [[Conversion to Christianity|Catholic convert]] from [[Judaism]] and a professed [[priest]] of the [[Carmelites]].{{citeweb|url=http://ocarm.org/en/content/liturgy/st-angelus-priest-and-martyr-m|title=St. Angelus, Priest and Martyr (M)|date=|publisher=Order of Carmelites|accessdate=13 October 2017}}{{citeweb|url=https://catholicsaints.info/saint-angelus-of-jerusalem/|title=Saint Angelus of Jerusalem|publisher=Saints SQPN|date=5 May 2017|accessdate=13 October 2017}} He and his twin brother were converted to the faith once their mother did so while both became [[ordained]] priests and Carmelite friars. But unlike his brother he retreated into the desert to a hermitage after his ordination. But he emerged once he was instructed to go to the Italian mainland to evangelize as well as to meet with [[Pope Honorius III]] to have him approve a new rule for the Carmelites.{{citeweb|url=http://www.santiebeati.it/dettaglio/51875|title=Sant'Angelo da Gerusalemme (di Sicilia)|publisher=Santi e Beati|date=|accessdate=13 October 2017}} He was slain whilst preaching and was believed a saint after his death. The Carmelites venerated him as such until [[Pope Pius II]] beatified the slain priest during his pontificate circa 1459. ==Life== [[File:San Ángelo, de Antonio de Pereda y Salgado (Museo del Prado).jpg|thumb|left|Painting {{circa}} 1667 - [[Antonio de Pereda]].]] He was born in [[Jerusalem]] in 1185 to the [[Jewish]] parents Jesse and Maria. His mother later converted to [[Christianity|Roman Catholicism]] both he and his twin brother John were [[Baptism|baptised]] when she converted. His parents died while he was in his childhood and the Patriarch Nicodemus oversaw their education until the twins turned eighteen. He and his brother John entered the [[Carmelites]] aged eighteen at the Saint Anne [[convent]] near the [[Golden Gate (Jerusalem)|Golden Gate]] to commence their [[novitiate]]. The two could speak [[Greek language|Greek]] as well as both [[Latin]] and [[Hebrew]]. In 1210 he was [[ordained]] to the [[priesthood]] in Jerusalem and he travelled in [[Palestine (region)|Palestine]]. Miraculous cures were attributed to him around this time and his "acta" stated that he sought to avoid fame and withdrew to a hermitage in the desert (in imitation of [[Jesus Christ]]) when he was becoming popular for his miracles. He remained as a hermit on [[Mount Carmel]] when he was instructed in 1218Some sources suggest God instructed him in a vision. to leave for the Italian peninsula in order to preach against the [[Pataria|patarini]] as well as the [[Albigensians]] and the [[Bogomilism|Bulgars]]. He had likewise been instructed to go to [[Rome]] to obtain from [[Pope Honorius III]] confirmation of the new and definitive rule for the order (later granted in 1226). He set off on a Genoese ship on 1 April 1219 and stopped first in [[Messina]] before heading off to [[Civitavecchia]] before he ended up in Rome to meet with the pope. The friar preached in the [[Basilica of Saint John Lateran]] while in Rome where he met both [[Saint Francis of Assisi]] and [[Saint Dominic]]. It is said that he foretold that Francis would receive the [[stigmata]] while Francis foretold his premature death. From there he was a guest of the [[Basilian monks|Basilians]] in [[Palermo]] where he was for over a month before preaching in [[Agrigento]] for over a month before settling in Licata. He had healed seven [[lepers]] and the ailing [[Archbishop of Palermo]] Bernardo de Castanea while in Palermo. He settled on the Sicilian island though his fame as a wonderworker caused crowds to flock to him. He also had success in converting some Jews though most Jews in Palermo came to despise him for this since he himself was once Jewish. He wanted to convert a [[Cathar]] [[knight]] named Berenger (known also in sources as Berengarius). Tradition states that Berenger was living in [[incest]] and that the friar convinced the knight's companion to leave Berenger. Berenger became enraged and had him attacked in front of the church of Santi Filippo e Giacomo in [[Licata]] on 1 May 1220 and was struck with Berenger's sword five times. He died of his wounds within the week on 5 May and according to tradition asked for his assassin to be pardoned while urging the faithful not to avenge his death. He was buried at Santi Filippo e Giacomo. ==Sainthood== His sepulcher at Licata became a site of [[pilgrimage]]. The Carmelites venerated him as a saint from at least 1456 and the cult received papal approval from [[Pope Pius II]] at some stage during the latter's pontificate. His remains were moved in 1486 from a wooden casket to a silver urn before being moved to a more previous urn on 5 May 1623. His [[relics]] were [[translation (relics)|translated]] to a new church in Licata on 15 August 1662 and are now housed at Santa Maria del Carmine; the ending of a [[bubonic plague|plague]] in the [[Kingdom of Naples]] in 1656 was attributed to his intercession. He has - since 4 May 1626 - been known as the patron saint for Palermo. ==See also== * [[Hebrew Catholics]] ==Notes and references== {{Reflist}} {{commons category|Saint Angel from Jerusalem}} ==External links== * [http://www.ocarm.org/ Curia Generalizia dei Carmelitani] * [http://www.santiebeati.it/dettaglio/51875 Santi e Beati] {{it icon}} * [http://www.santuariosantangelo.it/ Santuario di Sant' Angelo da Gerusalemme (di Sicilia)] {{it icon}} {{Portal|Saints|Biography|Catholicism|Judaism|People|History|Italy|Israel|Palestine}} {{Canonization}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Angelus Of Jerusalem}} [[Category:1185 births]] [[Category:1220 deaths]] [[Category:13th-century Christian saints]] [[Category:13th-century Roman Catholic martyrs]] [[Category:13th-century venerated Christians]] [[Category:Carmelites]] [[Category:Carmelite saints]] [[Category:Converts to Roman Catholicism from Judaism]] [[Category:Israeli Roman Catholics]] [[Category:Murdered Roman Catholic priests]] [[Category:People from Jerusalem]] [[Category:Saints from the Holy Land]] [[Category:Twin people]] [[Category:Venerated Catholics]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox military person | image= Batoo_Tshering.jpg | caption= Batoo Tshering. | imagesize = | name= Batoo Tshering | death_date= | birth_date= {{Birth date and age|1951|12|11}} {{Cite web |url=http://www.rba.bt/chief |title=Royal Bhutan Army |access-date=2016-09-18 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160904031629/http://www.rba.bt/chief |archive-date=2016-09-04 |dead-url=yes |df= }} | birth_place= Toebesa, [[Thimphu]], [[Bhutan]] | death_place= | placeofburial= | nickname= | allegiance={{flag|Bhutan}} | branch=[[Royal Bhutan Army]] | serviceyears= 1971 - current | rank= [[Lieutenant General]] | commands= | battles= [[Operation All Clear]] | awards= Druk Yugyel Medal
Drakpoi Wangyel Medal
Drakpoi Thugsey Medal
Drakpoi Khorlo Medal
Drakpoi Rinchen Tsugtor Medal |laterwork= | religion = [[Buddhism]] }} ''Goongloen Gongma'' ([[Lt General]]) '''Batoo Tshering''', DYG, DW, DT, DK,{{cite web|last=Buyers|first=Christopher|title=Orders And Decorations|url=http://www.royalark.net/Bhutan/bhutan5.htm|accessdate=2013-04-22}} is the current Chief Operations Officer of the Royal Bhutan Army (COO).{{cite news|title=Officers promoted to rank of Lieutenant Colonel|url=http://www.bbs.bt/news/?p=23478|accessdate=2013-04-22|date=2013-02-13}} He succeeded the outgoing chief, ''Goongloen Gongma'' ([[Lieutenant General]]) '''[[Lam Dorji]]''' on 1 November 2005.{{cite news|title=Dozin Batoo Tshering takes over as COO of RBA|newspaper=Kuensel|date=2005-11-02}}{{cite web|title=RANK INSIGNIA - ARMY LAND FORCES|url=http://www.uniforminsignia.org/?option=com_insigniasearch&Itemid=53&result=2931|accessdate=2013-04-22}} ==Family== Tshering is married to ''Aum'' Pema Choden, who is a graduate of [[Paro College of Education]] and they have two daughters, Dechen Yangden & Rinchen Pelden, both of whom are employed with the Royal Government of [[Bhutan]].{{cite news|title=The Person in Me|newspaper=Kuensel|date=2006-01-14}} His Daughter Rinchen Pelden is Married to Singye Namgayl Dorji and they have three children, Tseten Dradul Dorji(14), Thinley Uma Peldron(8), and Zukyi Nema(2). ==Military career== Tshering underwent training at [[Indian Military Academy]]{{cite news|title=284 cadets from OTA set to join army|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2012-03-18/chennai/31207134_1_cadets-ota-indian-military-academy|accessdate=2013-04-22|newspaper=The Times Of India|date=March 18, 2012}} and got commissioned into the [[Royal Bhutan Army]] in November 1971. Thereafter, he was attached with the [[Indian Army]] and underwent Young Officers Course, [[Commando Course]], Intelligence Staff Officers’ Course, Junior Command Course, Senior Command Course in various schools of instruction in [[India]]. He is also a graduate of the prestigious [[Defense Services Staff College]], [[Wellington, Tamil Nadu]]. [[Lt Gen]] Batoo Tshering has held various important staff and command assignments. His first staff posting was at the Army Headquarters (AHQ) as Operations and Training Officer in 1976. He commanded Wing 4 and Wing 7 in succession. He was the Commandant of Military Training Centre in 1988, Deputy Chief Operations Officer (G) in 1991 and Commander of Command Centre at [[Dewathang Gewog|Dewathang]] in 1997 till the completion of Operation: All Clear in 2003.{{cite web|last=PRABHAKARA|first=M.S.|title=Crackdown in Bhutan|url=http://www.frontline.in/navigation/?type=static&page=flonnet&rdurl=fl2101/stories/20040116006400400.htm|accessdate=2013-04-22}} He took over as the Deputy Chief Operations Officer with effect from 21 February 2005 and was appointed as the Chief Operations Officer by His Majesty King [[Jigme Singye Wangchuck]] on 1 November 2005.{{cite news|last=Pandit|first=Rajat|title=Bhutanese Army chief, Major General Batoo Tshering, began his official visit to India on Wednesday, during which India and Bhutan will seek to enhance their bilateral military ties. Maj General Tshering will hold talks with defence minister A K Antony and the three Service chiefs during the day.|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/home/Bhutanese-Army-chief-Major-General-Batoo-Tshering-began-his-official-visit-to-India-on-Wednesday-during-which-India-and-Bhutan-will-seek-to-enhance-their-bilateral-military-ties-Maj-General-Tshering-will-hold-talks-with-defence-minister-A-K-Antony-and-the-three-Service-chiefs-during-the-day-/articleshow/12259919.cms|accessdate=2013-04-22|newspaper=The Times of India|date=2012-03-14}} In addition to his responsibilities as the Chief Operations Officer, he is also the Chairman of the Board of Directors of the Army Welfare Project.{{cite web |title=Army Welfare Project |url=http://www.awp.com.bt/index.php |accessdate=2013-04-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121028015238/http://www.awp.com.bt/index.php |archivedate=2012-10-28 |df= }} While on active duty Tshering survived an ambush from armed insurgents near [[Nganglam]] on Oct 31, 1998, during which his car was riddled with bullet shots and he was injured. ==Awards and decorations== For his dedicated and distinguished service to the ''Tsa-Wa-Sum'' (King, Country and People), he was awarded ''Druk Yugyel'' (DYG), ''Drakpoi Wangyel'' (DW), ''Drakpoi Thugsey'' (DT) and ''Drakpoi Khorlo'' (DK) medals by His Majesty King [[Jigme Singye Wangchuck]].{{cite news|title=His Majesty the King awards decoration medals |url=http://www.kuenselonline.com/his-majesty-the-king-awards-decoration-medals/#.UXUte-BAh_l |accessdate=2013-04-22 |newspaper=Kuensel |date=2001-12-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140223115014/http://www.kuenselonline.com/his-majesty-the-king-awards-decoration-medals/ |archivedate=2014-02-23 |df= }} He was also awarded the ''Drakpoi Rinchen Tsugtor'' (DRT) medal by His Majesty the King on 21 February 2013.{{cite news |title=HM awards medals on the occasion |url=http://www.kuenselonline.com/hm-awards-medals-on-the-occasion-2/#.UXUtbeBAh_l |accessdate=2013-04-22 |newspaper=Kuensel |date=2013-02-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130504055844/http://www.kuenselonline.com/hm-awards-medals-on-the-occasion-2/#.UXUtbeBAh_l |archivedate=2013-05-04 |df= }} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Tshering, B}} [[Category:1951 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Military of Bhutan]] [[Category:Army personnel]] [[Category:Bhutanese people]] [[Category:People from Thimphu]]

{{Infobox person | name = Benoni W. Urey | image = Benoni Urey.jpg | alt = | caption = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1957|06|22}} | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | monuments = | residence = | nationality = | other_names = | citizenship = [[Liberia]] | education = Masters degree | alma_mater = [[Cuttington University]];
[[University of Southern California]] | occupation = | years_active = | employer = | organization = | agent = | known_for = Being Liberia's richest man; business holdings; association with [[Charles Taylor (Liberian politician)|Charles Taylor]] | style = | home_town = | salary = | net_worth = | height = | weight = | television = | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | movement = | opponents = | boards = | spouse = Mai Bright Urey | partner = | children = Danielle Urey, Telia Urey, Jebbeh Urey, Benita Urey, Frederick Jallah-Urey, Christopher Jallah-Urey, Henry Costa-Urey [http://cuttington.net/newsreleases.html] Cuttington University, accessed June 9, 2014 | parents = Emma Urey and Daniel Webster Urey IV | relatives = | callsign = | awards = | website = | footnotes = }} '''Benoni W. Urey''' (born June 22, 1957) is an [[Americo-Liberian]] businessman and politician, who was formerly the Liberian Commissioner of Maritime Affairs. In 2014 ''[[The Economist]]'' reported that Urey was Liberia's wealthiest man.[https://www.economist.com/blogs/baobab/2014/01/vying-popular-vote-liberia, "'Goldfinger' and the presidency"] ''The Economist'', January 18, 2014. == Early life and career == Urey was born on June 22, 1957 at his family home in [[Careysburg]], Montserrado County, [[Liberia]]. His father was married to three women, his mother, Emma Boyce Urey, Martha Urey and Kpannah Urey. Two of his mothers were [[Kpelle people|Kpelle]] and one was Americo-Liberian. His father, Daniel Urey, was an Americo-Liberian from Careysburg. Urey’s father met two of his wives in Caresyburg and one in Bong County. Two of Urey's mothers were dominantly native women who never spoke English, while the other was a school teacher. His father was subsistence farmer. This family lived in Careysburg throughout their lives.[http://cuttington.net/newsreleases.html Cuttington University, "Cuttington Honors Two of her own!!"], undated. Benoni is the eighth of eleven children. He attended kindergarten and first grade at Careysburg Public School. With the aid of a scholarship from the U.S. government through the Voice of America relay station, Urey attended the American Cooperative School (A.C.S), a private American school in Monrovia, from first grade until his graduation from high school in 1976. While attending A.C.S, he participated in almost every varsity sport, including basketball. His love for basketball led him and some friends to form The Uhuru Kings and Queens, a social and sports club that eventually became a first division member of Liberia Basketball Federation. Uhuru Kings still is a member of the Liberian Basketball Federation and has participated in numerous national championships over the years.[http://allafrica.com/stories/200205220335.html] AllAfrica.com, "Liberia: In LBf League Best of Five Series Finals: Oilers, U-Kings Battle in Game I Today - As Bushrod Bulls Host Flames in Game II", 22 May 2002 After high school, Urey attended [[Cuttington University]], in [[Bong County]]. He earned a Bachelor of Science Degree in General Science with emphasis in chemistry in 1980. At Cuttington University, Urey served as the President of The Mason Social and Athletic Club, and in his last year, President of the Senior class. Later in 2010, Urey was awarded the Doctor of Humane Letters (L.H.D.) ''Honoris Causa'' from Cuttington University. After university, Urey moved to Monrovia and began to work for the government, at the Liberia Electricity Corporation (LEC). He worked as a Training Officer until he was awarded a scholarship to pursue a M.A. in Public Finance and Human Resource Development and a M.Sc in Planning from the [[University of Southern California]]. He graduated from USC in 1986.[http://www.winne.com/liberia/to02interv.html Winne.com "Interview with: Mr. Benoni W. Urey"], June 21, 2001. Upon his return to Liberia in 1986, Benoni was appointed Deputy Director General for Planning and Training of the Liberia Electricity Corporation Training Center under the Presidency of the late [[Samuel Doe|President Samuel K. Doe]]. He worked at the corporation until the war broke out. In 1989, when the [[First Liberian Civil War|Liberian Civil War]] broke out, Urey left Liberia and traveled to Sierra Leone and lived there for eight months and later moved to the Ivory Coast.{{Citation needed|date=June 2014}} While there, he started to work at [[African Development Bank]] as a consultant. In 1994, Urey returned to Bong County, Liberia and started to work as the Managing Director at Liberia Rubber Development Corporation. == Political career == {{POV section|date=July 2014}} {{Dispute about|'''inadequate references, and the unsubstantiated linking of the subject to Viktor Bout'''|date=July 2014}} Under the Interim Government of Liberia, chaired by [[Wilton G. S. Sankawulo|Wilton Sankawulo]], in 1995, Urey was appointed President of Agricultural Cooperative Development Bank of Liberia. In 1996, the Council of State appointed Urey as Commissioner of Maritime Affairs. When [[Charles Taylor (Liberian politician)|Charles Taylor]] came to power after winning elections in 1997, Urey was reappointed to his position as Commissioner of Maritime. He served as Commissioner until 2003, when Taylor resigned from office. In 2000 Urey was sanctioned by the [[United Nations]] for his alleged role in arms procurement (starting in summer of 2002) and also for his alleged “ongoing ties with [[Charles Taylor (Liberian politician)|Charles Taylor]]”.[https://www.un.org/sc/committees/1521/pdf/1521_assets_freeze_list.pdf United Nations, January 21, 2013] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111130122038/http://www.un.org/sc/committees/1521/pdf/1521_assets_freeze_list.pdf |date=November 30, 2011 }} Urey breached an earlier UN travel ban in August 2001.[https://www.un.org/Docs/sc/committees/Liberia2/1015e.pdf Report of the Panel of Experts pursuant to Security Council resolution 1343] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121007155659/http://www.un.org/Docs/sc/committees/Liberia2/1015e.pdf |date=October 7, 2012 }}, page 93.{{cite web|url=http://www.gov.im/news/2014/feb/07/financial-sanctions-liberia/ |title=Isle of Man Government - Financial Sanctions: Liberia |publisher=Gov.im |date=2014-02-07 |accessdate=2014-04-08}} His name was added to the [[US Treasury Department]]'s [[Specially Designated Nationals]] list, prohibiting him from conducting business with US companies, citizens and residents, and blocking all US based assets.[http://www.treasury.gov/ofac/downloads/t11sdn.pdf US Treasury Department, "Specially Designated Nationals and Blocked Persons List"], April 9, 2014.[http://www.treasury.gov/resource-center/sanctions/Documents/liberia.pdf US Treasury Department, "An overview of the Former Liberian Regime of Charles Taylor Sanctions Regulations -- Title 31 Part 593 of the U.S. Code of Federal Regulations"], May 23, 2007. A 2005 report from the Coalition for International Justice reported that Urey helped Taylor "siphon off" funds from a shipping firm to pay for arms and was the primary contact between Taylor and [[Viktor Bout]].[http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2012/08/11/firm-that-paid-white-house-adviser-in-business-with-charles-taylor-tied/ FoxNews.com, "Firm that paid Obama adviser in business with warlord-tied official"], August 11, 2012.[http://www.liberianobserver.com/security/benoni-urey-de-listed-un-ban-pro-or-con-liberia Liberian Observer, "Benoni Urey De-Listed From UN Ban: Pro Or Con For Liberia"], January 12, 2014.{{cite web |url=http://allafrica.com/download/resource/main/main/idatcs/00010642:e0bc9e66f665f2c7b2fb8a942ff328ea.pdf |title=Following Taylor's Money: A path of war and destruction |author=Douglas Farah, CIJ |date=May 2005}} The United Nations Panel of Experts concluded in their November 2013 report that "evidence indicates, however, that in approving the funds Urey was acting on the orders of Taylor."{{cite web |url=https://www.un.org/News/Press/docs/2013/sc11229.doc.htm |title=Letter dated 19 November 2013 from the Chair of the Security Council Committee established pursuant to resolution 1521 (2003) concerning Liberia addressed to the President of the Security Council |date=21 November 2013}} The [[Liberian Truth and Reconciliation Commission]] (TRC) recommended in its final report that Urey be prosecuted for the commission of economic crimes during the civil war and barred from holding public office for 30 years.[http://trcofliberia.org/resources/reports/final/volume-two_layout-1.pdf], Liberian Truth and Reconciliation Commission, Consolidated Final Report, June 30, 2009. During the TRC hearings, Urey was identified by witness James Paul as operating the Liberian Rubber Company and exporting "hundred of thousands of tons of rubber", the proceeds of which were never accounted for.[http://trcofliberia.org/transcripts/11] TRC Hearing transcripts, Monrovia: Day 9, January 22, 2008 Urey has denied any involvement in the violence of the Liberian and [[Sierra Leone]] civil conflicts, maintaining that as a civilian being appointed to head the Maritime Commission, he made no war-related decisions. An investigation by the United Nations Panel of Experts on Liberia's political situation in 2013 concluded that it “did not have information suggesting that Urey was involved in activities that would destabilize Liberia and the subregion”. The Panel also stated that “Urey’s business activities, and the profits gained from them, would appear to suggest that civil conflict in Liberia would have a significant negative financial impact on him”. In December 2013, Urey was de-listed from the United Nations Sanction Lists. In November 2015 the US Treasury Department lifted sanctions against a number of Liberians, including Urey.{{cite web|url=http://www.voanews.com/content/liberia-welcomes-lifting-of-us-sanctions/3056149.html |title=Liberia Welcomes Lifting of US Sanctions |publisher=Voice of America |date=2015-11-13}} A Liberian newspaper reportedly that Urey was subsequently denied a US entry visa in 2016, a claim which was denied by the All Liberian Party.{{cite web|url=http://gnnliberia.com/2016/04/26/alp-clarifies-ureys-u-s-entry-visa-denial/ |title=ALP Clarifies On Urey’s U.S. Entry Visa Denial |publisher=GNN Liberia |date=2016-04-26}} In 2009, Urey was elected Mayor of Careysburg City by the City Council. [[Ellen Johnson Sirleaf|President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf]] endorsed the appointment by subsequently appointing him Mayor. He served as Mayor until 2012.{{citation needed|date=June 2014}} President Sirleaf relieved Urey of this post when it became evident that he would not support her in re-election bid in 2011, instead, supporting the Congress for Democratic Change. == Business career == === Lonestar Cell === Urey currently owns [[Lonestar Cell|Lonestar Communication Corporation]], Liberia's largest mobile phone service provider which is partnered with the [[MTN Group]], through his PLC Investments group. Lonestar is one of the largest taxpayers in Liberia. Urey has served as the Chairman of the Board since the establishment of the corporation.{{cite web |url=http://www.frontpageafricaonline.com/index.php/politic/238-off-un-ban-into-politics-what-s-next-for-benoni-urey |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-01-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140206020049/http://www.frontpageafricaonline.com/index.php/politic/238-off-un-ban-into-politics-what-s-next-for-benoni-urey |archivedate=2014-02-06 |df= }} FrontPageAfrica, OFF UN BAN, RIGHT INTO POLITICS? WHAT'S NEXT FOR BENONI UREY, December 29, 2013. === Wulki Farms I & II === Urey established an agricultural farm and resort in Careysburg City, Wulki Farms I and Farmers Paradise Resort, developed on land owned by his father, Daniel Webster Urey IV. Benoni’s wife, Mai Urey, is the Managing Director of Wulki Farms and Farmers Paradise. The property includes commercial production of poultry and eggs, fish and fresh produce and guest accommodation.[http://www.wulkifarms.com/index-3.html "About Wulki Farms"], accessed January 30, 2014. Urey owns the sixth largest rubber plantation, Wulki Farms II, located in Konola, Margibi County.{{Citation needed|date=May 2018}} === Love Media Incorporated === Owned solely by Urey, Love Media Incorporated was established in 2003 and comprises radio and television stations and a newspaper. These stations are based in Monrovia and Careysburg City. Shiata FM, another station owned by Urey, was established in 2005 and is based in Careysburg City. During the 2011 election campaign, Love Radio and TV stations were set on fire. Urey accused the Government of being involved in the burning of his stations because he was a financial supporter of the opposition party, Congress for Democratic Change. === U-Housing Incorporated === U-Housing is a real estate development company owned by Urey. He began developing real estate in 1994 when he returned to Liberia. U-Housing has acquired and developed a wide range of commercial and residential properties throughout the country. == 2017 Presidential Elections == In December 2013 Urey declared his desire to run for the Presidency of Liberia in 2017, with initial speculation in Liberian media that he would do so with the Congress for Democratic Change party headed by former footballer [[George Weah]]. Urey subsequently launched the All Liberian Party in November 2015 at the [[Antoinette Tubman]] Stadium in Monrovia.[http://allafrica.com/stories/201511050666.html Front Page Africa, "Liberia: Benoni Urey Eyes Transformation in New Political Manifesto"], November 5, 2015. == Personal life == Urey married to Mai Bright Urey on May 26, 1986. They have four daughters: Danielle Ashlee Urey, Telia Urey, Jebbeh Naomi Urey and Benita Whitney Urey. He is a Christian. He was born and raised Presbyterian and serves as the sexton at the First Presbyterian Church of Careysburg. Urey is fluent in English and his native dialect, [[Kpelle language|Kpelle]].{{Citation needed|date=June 2014}} Urey also serves as “Deputy District Grand Master” of the Grand Lodge of the [[Freemasonry]] Republic of Liberia and Honorable Grand Patron of the [[Order of the Eastern Star]] of Liberia. == References == {{reflist|2}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Urey, Benoni}} [[Category:1957 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Liberian people]] [[Category:Candidates for President of Liberia]] [[Category:People from Montserrado County]] [[Category:Cuttington University alumni]] [[Category:Liberian Presbyterians]] [[Category:Americo-Liberian people]] [[Category:University of Southern California people]]

{{no footnotes|date=July 2013}} '''Bill Chalker''' is an Australian author and [[UFO]] researcher. He is a contributing editor for the ''International UFO Reporter'' and has been the Australian representative for the Aerial Phenomena Research Organisation (1978 to 1986) and a [[New South Wales]] state representative for the [[Mutual UFO Network]] (1976 to 1993).
==Biography== Chalker was born in [[Grafton, New South Wales]] in 1952. He studied at the [[University of New England (Australia)|University of New England]], receiving a degree in chemistry and mathematics.
==Bibliography== *{{cite book|author=Bill Chalker|title=The Oz Files: The Australian UFO Story|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZAyspwAACAAJ|accessdate=16 July 2013|date=1 January 1996|publisher=Duffy and Snellgrove|isbn=978-1-875989-04-1}} *{{cite book|author=Bill Chalker|title=Hair of the Alien: DNA and Other Forensic Evidence of Alien Abductions|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hMh5hBuKZhMC|accessdate=16 July 2013|date=19 August 2005|publisher=[[Pocket Books]]|isbn=978-1-4165-1024-6}}
==References== {{Reflist}} *[http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/news/national/bill-chalker-the-aussie-x-files-agent-who-says-the-aliens-have-landed/story-e6freuzr-1225845013217 "Bill Chalker, the Aussie X-Files agent who says the aliens have landed"], ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'', March 25, 2010 *Chalker, Bill. [http://trove.nla.gov.au/work/68797401?q=%22bill+chalker%22&l-format=Article&c=article&versionId=81942553 ''Hair of the Alien: DNA and Other Forensic Evidence for Alien Abductions''].(Brief Article)(Book Review) ''[[Booklist]]'', v.101, no.21, 2005 July, p. 1880 *[http://trove.nla.gov.au/work/152211860?q=%22bill+chalker%22&l-format=Article&l-availability=y&l-format=Article%2FOther+article&c=article&versionId=165909580 "Australia loses UFO documents"], UPI NewsTrack, 2011 June 9. Quote by Chalker as UFO expert. *[http://trove.nla.gov.au/work/116453155?q=%22bill+chalker%22&l-format=Article&l-availability=y&l-format=Article%2FOther+article&c=article&versionId=129923647 "Up-to-date aliens grey not green, experts tell UFO fans."], Asia Africa Intelligence Wire (Financial Times), 2002 August 5. Quote by Chalker as UFO expert. *"UFOs leaving traces UFOs leaving traces." ''Hornsby and Upper North Shore Advocate'' (New South Wales, Australia). (May 20, 2010) News: p14 *"Space oddity." ''Hills Shire Times'' (New South Wales, Australia). (May 11, 2010) News: p1. *"UFO sighting probed." ''Macarthur Chronicle'' (New South Wales, Australia). (Mar. 30, 2010) News: p7. *"Division over UFOs." ''mX Sydney'' (New South Wales, Australia). (Mar. 24, 2010) News: p5. *"Close encounters." ''The Sun-Herald'' (Sydney, Australia). (Feb. 21, 2010) News: p5. *"Spike", ''Sydney Morning Herald'', 04/24/2001 *"THE TRUTH IS OUT THERE." ''Daily Telegraph'' (Sydney, New South Wales, Australia). (July 20, 1996) Regional News: p034 *"Revealed: SA's alien spaceship secrets; New book tells of; our close encounters." ''The Sunday Mail'' (Adelaide, South Australia, Australia). (July 21, 1996) News: p030. *"Family's terror in Nullarbor incident." ''The Sunday Mail'' (Adelaide, South Australia, Australia). (July 21, 1996) News: p030. Quote: "Bill Chalker is the only researcher given access to government UFO files." *"UFO FILES." ''The Sunday Mail'' (QLD) (Brisbane, Queensland, Australia). (Aug. 11, 1996) News: p068. *"STRANGER THAN FICTION." ''The Australian'' (National, Australia). (Dec. 11, 1996) Regional News: pB12.
==External links== *http://www.auforn.com/Bcintro.htm *http://theozfiles.blogspot.ca/ *http://authors.simonandschuster.ca/Bill-Chalker/22509695 *http://www.forteantimes.com/strangedays/ufofiles/516/bill_chalkers_ufo_top_ten.html *http://www.project1947.com/forum/bcbiog.htm

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | title = | name = Chandan Biswas
চন্দন বিশ্বাস | image = Cyclist Chandan Biswas.jpg 01.jpg | image_size = | birth_name = Chandan Biswas | birth_date = 5 November 1985 | birth_place = [[Patna]], [[Bihar]] | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = [[India]]n | ethnicity = | religion = | alma_mater = | occupation = Explorer
Cyclist }} '''Chandan Biswas''' (born 5 November 1985) is a [[Bengalis|Bengali]] [[Adventure sports]] personnel and Travel Writer. ==Expeditions== Biswas started adventure sports since 2010. He involves with [[mountaineering]], [[rock climbing]] and [[mountain cycling]] also. He was the first who completed the Solo [[Transhimalaya|Trans-Himalaya]] Cycling Expedition. He took part in February 2017 and successfully finished in July 2017.{{Cite web|url=https://bengali.news18.com/news/chandan-biswas-completed-his-trans-himalayan-expedition-on-bicycle-144345.html|title=দু’চাকায় ট্রান্স হিমালয় জয়, নজির গড়ল বাঙালি ছেলে|last=|first=|date=|website=bengali.news18.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=July 7, 2018}} In this journey Biswas cycled 6,249 km through the countries of [[Bangladesh]], [[Bhutan]], [[Nepal]] and [[India]].{{Cite web|url=http://epaper.thestatesman.com/1188297/Siliguri-The-Statesman/29th-April-2017#page/14/2|title=HNAF fetes cyclist for completing half of Himalayan trek|last=|first=|date=April 29, 2017|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=July 7, 2018}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.anandabazar.com/district/north-bengal/chandan-biswas-a-bicycle-rider-capturing-life-through-the-lens-1.604848?ref=chandan-biswas-topics-topic-stry|title=ছবির নেশায় সঙ্গী সাইকেল|last=|first=|date=|website=anandabazar.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=July 7, 2018}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.dreamwanderlust.com/news/trans-himalayan-cycle-expedition-by-chandan-biswas|title=Trans-Himalayan Cycling Expedition by Chandan Biswas|last=|first=|date=July 10, 2017|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=July 7, 2018}} In 2016 he led Intra-Country Cycling and Running Expedition team from [[Kolkata]] to [[Dhaka]] to pay tribute to the martyrs of the [[Bengali language movement|Language Movement]] ahead of the [[International Mother Language Day]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.clickittefaq.com/indian-cyclists-travel-to-bangladesh-to-pay-respect-to-martyrs/|title=Indian cyclists travel to Bangladesh to pay respect to language martyrs|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=July 7, 2018}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.prothomalo.com/bangladesh/article/773035/%E0%A6%A2%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%95%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%B0-%E0%A6%AA%E0%A6%A5%E0%A7%87-%E0%A6%AD%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%B0%E0%A6%A4%E0%A7%80%E0%A7%9F-%E0%A6%85%E0%A6%95%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%B7%E0%A6%B0%E0%A6%AF%E0%A6%BE%E0%A6%A4%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%B0%E0%A6%BE-%E0%A6%A6%E0%A6%B2%E0%A7%87%E0%A6%B0-%E0%A6%9B%E0%A7%9F-%E0%A6%B8%E0%A6%A6%E0%A6%B8%E0%A7%8D%E0%A6%AF|title=ঢাকার পথে ভারতীয় অক্ষরযাত্রা দলের ছয় সদস্য|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=July 7, 2018}}{{Cite book|title=Akkhsarjatra|last=Vol 3, Issue 11|first=|publisher=Long Jounrey|year=2016|isbn=|location=Kolkata|pages=98–100|issn=2455-1767}} His upcoming Solo Narmada Walk adventure, throughout the [[Narmada River|Narmada river]] will cover 1300 km including 4 states of India.{{Cite web|url=http://www.sangbadpratidin.in/hridaypur-youth-going-to-explore-1300-km-long-narmada-river-by-walk/|title=পায়ে হেঁটে নর্মদার মোহনা থেকে উৎস পরিক্রমা|last=|first=|date=|website=sangbadpratidin.in|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=July 7, 2018}} == See more == * [[Ramnath Biswas]] * [[Bimal Mukherjee]] * [[Maxwell Trevor]] revision.text:
{{Chinese|pic=lingyin_temple_18_armed_cundi.jpeg|san={{IAST|Cundī}}|t=準提觀音|s=准提观音|p=Zhǔntí Guānyīn|w=Chun<sup>3</sup>-t'i<sup>2</sup> Kuan<sup>1</sup>-yin<sup>1</sup>|l=Cundi Guanyin|t2=準提菩薩|s2=准提菩萨|p2=Zhǔntí Púsà|l2=Cundi Bodhisattva|w2=Chun<sup>3</sup>-t'i<sup>2</sup> P'u<sup>2</sup>-sa<sup>4</sup>|kanji=准胝観音|romaji=Juntei Kannon|qn=Quán âm Chuẩn Đề}}
[[Image:Cundi Ming Dynasty Gold.png|thumb|right|[[Ming dynasty|Ming Chinese]] gold painting of Cundi. Hanging scroll, gold ink and colors on paper.]]
'''{{IAST|Cundī}}''' ({{bo|w=skul byed ma}}, {{zh|t=準提菩薩}}) is a minor female deity in [[Vajrayana]].
{{IAST|Cundī}} appears with eighteen arms on a lotus and is referred to as "Goddess of the Seventy Million [Buddhas]".<ref name=PDB>{{cite book |editor1-last=Buswell |editor1-first=Robert E. |editor2-last=Lopez |editor2-first=Donald S. |title=The Princeton Dictionary of Buddhism |publisher=Princeton University Press |location=NJ |isbn=978-0-691-15786-3|page=204}}</ref>
==In Buddhist traditions== While Cundi is less well known in Tibetan Buddhism, she is revered in Tangmi or East Asian esoteric Buddhism. In China, she is known as ''Zhǔntí Púsà'' ({{zh|t=準提菩薩}}, "Cundi Bodhisattva") or ''Zhǔntí Fómǔ'' ({{zh|t=準提佛母}}, "Cundi Buddha-Mother"), "Chunje" in Korean, while in Japan she is known as {{nihongo|Juntei Kannon|准胝観音|Cundi Avalokiteśvara}}.
In [[History of China#late imperial China|late imperial China]], early traditions of Tangmi were still thriving in Buddhist communities. Robert Gimello has also observed that in these communities, the esoteric practices of Cundi were extremely popular among both the populace and the elite.<ref>Gimello, Robert (2004). ″Icon and Incantation: The Goddess Zhunti and the Role of Images in the Occult Buddhism of China." In ''Images in Asian Religions: Texts and Contexts'' ed. Phyllis Granoff and Koichi Shinohara: pp. 71-85.</ref>
==Source texts== The first textual source of Cundi and the Cundī Dhāraṇī is the ''{{IAST|[[Kāraṇḍavyūhasūtra]]}}'', a sūtra centered around the bodhisattva [[Avalokiteśvara]] that introduced the popular mantra ''{{IAST|[[om mani padme hum|oṃ maṇipadme hūṃ]]}}''.<ref name="Studholme, Alexander 2002 p. 175">Studholme, Alexander (2002) ''The origins of Oṃ maṇipadme hūṃ: a study of the Kāraṇḍavyūha sūtra'': p. 175</ref> This text is first dated to around the late 4th century CE to the early 5th century CE.<ref>Studholme, Alexander (2002) ''The origins of Oṃ maṇipadme hūṃ: a study of the Kāraṇḍavyūha sūtra'': p. 17</ref> Cundi and the Cundī Dhāraṇī are also featured in the [[Cundī Dhāraṇī Sūtra]], which was translated three times from Sanskrit to [[Chinese language|Chinese]] in the late 7th century and early 8th century by the Indian esoteric masters [[Divakara|Divākara]] (685 CE), [[Vajrabodhi]] (723 CE), and [[Amoghavajra]] (8th century).<ref name="Studholme, Alexander 2002 p. 175"/>
==Cundī Dhāraṇī == {{main article|Cundī Dhāraṇī }} According to the ''{{IAST|Cundī Dhāraṇī Sūtra}}'', the [[dhāraṇī]] associated with Cundī is the following:<ref name="The Cundī Dhāraṇī Sūtra">[http://lapislazulitexts.com/cundi_dharani_sutra.html ''The Cundī Dhāraṇī Sūtra'']</ref> :''{{IAST|namaḥ saptānāṃ samyaksaṃbuddha koṭīnāṃ tadyathā}}'' :''{{IAST|oṃ cale cule cundī svāhā}}'' In the sūtra, the Buddha speaks extensively about the various effects and benefits of reciting the Cundī dhāraṇī. Many of the effects are purifying and uplifting in nature. For example, after pronouncing the dhāraṇī, the Buddha then says:<ref name="The Cundī Dhāraṇī Sūtra"/> {{quote|If there are [[bhikkhu|bhikṣus]], [[bhikkhuni|bhikṣuṇīs]], [[Upāsaka and Upāsikā|upāsakas, or upāsikās]] who memorize and recite this dhāraṇī 800,000 times, their deadly [[karma]] in every place, created over innumerable eons, will be completely annihilated. In every place where they are born or reside, they will always meet buddhas and bodhisattvas. They will always have adequate resources and abilities to do as they wish. In any birth, they will always be able to leave the home life, and will have the ability to maintain the pure precepts of a bodhisattva. They will be born in human or heavenly realms, they will not fall into evil destinies, and they will always be protected by all the heavenly guardians.}} The dhāraṇī is also closely associated with [[buddhahood]] and complete [[bodhi|enlightenment]] (Skt. ''{{IAST|Anuttarā Samyaksaṃbodhi}}''). At the end of the sūtra, the Buddha closes the teaching by saying:<ref name="The Cundī Dhāraṇī Sūtra"/> {{quote|This great dhāraṇī of Cundī is a great brilliant mantra teaching that is spoken by all buddhas of the past, all buddhas of the future, and all buddhas of the present time. I also now speak it thusly to benefit all sentient beings, causing them to attain Anuttarā Samyaksaṃbodhi. If there are sentient beings with little merit, who lack the roots of goodness, natural ability, and the [[Seven Factors of Enlightenment|Factors of Bodhi]], if they obtain hearing of this dhāraṇī method, they will quickly realize the attainment of Anuttarā Samyaksaṃbodhi. If there are people who are always able to remember, recite, and maintain this dhāraṇī, they will all obtain immeasurable roots of goodness.}}
==Iconography== Cundi is depicted with eighteen arms, each wielding implements that symbolize [[upaya]]. Her eighteen arms also represent the eighteen merits of attaining Buddhahood as described in an appendix to the ''{{IAST|Cundī Dhāraṇī Sūtra}}''.
==See also== *[[Pure Land Buddhism]] *[[Chandi]]
==References== {{wikisource|Cundī Dhāraṇī Sūtra}} {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://lapislazulitexts.com/cundi_dharani_sutra.html English translation of the ''Cundī Dhāraṇī Sūtra'']

{{EngvarB|date=February 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2018}} [[File:Dugald Semple.jpg|upright|thumb|Dugald Semple.]] '''Dugald Semple''' (1884–1964), was a Scottish advocate of "[[simple living]]", a naturalist, prolific author, and [[Fruitarianism|fruitarian]].<ref name=ft>[http://www.happycow.net/blog/cathie-dugald-semple-vegan-pioneers/ Cathie & Dugald Semple] Retrieved : 26 March 2014</ref> He is sometimes credited with cofounding the [[vegan]] movement in 1944 (with Dorothy and [[Donald Watson]] and other friends) without using the term 'vegan'.<ref>[http://www.happycow.net/blog/joys-of-the-simple-life/ Edmundson, J. ‘Joys Of The Simple Life’ – By Dugald Semple – Now 100 Years Old, o1/23/2015, accessed 02/01/2015]</ref> Semple's mother hailed from a farm near [[Beith]], and his father worked as a tailor. He was born in [[Johnstone]] near Paisley, Scotland.<ref name="D">Abrams, Page 186</ref> Cathie Amos was his wife, who predeceased him, dying of heart failure in 1941,<ref name=ft/> Dugald died in [[Fairlie, North Ayrshire|Fairlie]].<ref name="D"/> They had no children, although Cathie had a son, Ian, who was killed in World War I.<ref name=ft/>
==Life== Dugald won a bursary to Paisley Grammar School and served an apprenticeship as an engineering draughtsman. In 1907 he moved into a tent, and later an old omnibus located on Linwood Moss.<ref name="D"/> In 1916 he was a [[conscientious objector]] and thus exempted from [[military service]] on condition that he continued lecturing on food economy.<ref name="D"/> [[File:Davies o'the Mill ruins.jpg|thumb|left|250px|Davie's o'the Mill ruins in 2011.]] [[File:Davie's o'the Mill homestead ruins.jpg|250px|thumb|Ruins of the mill.]] Dugald Semple, [[veganism|vegan]] and 'Scottish Apostle of the simple life,'<ref>[http://www.ivu.org/history/societies/scottish.html Scottish Vegetarian Society] Retrieved ; 17 September 2011</ref> farmed at Davie's o'the Mill near [[Beith]] in [[North Ayrshire]] from the 1930s until around 1950, when it was a smallholding. Dugald was a hippy before hippies officially existed and started living in an army tent from 1907. He was sometimes known as the 'Hut Man' from living in his 'hut on wheels' or caravan<ref name=VA/> and therefore probably did not live in the house. He later lived in [[Fairlie, North Ayrshire|Fairlie]].<ref name=S/> Semple preached self-responsibility and care for others.<ref name=S>[http://news.scotsman.com/obituaries/John-Macfarlane.2802337.jp The Scotsman] Retrieved : 19 September 2011</ref> Curiously for a vegetarian he appears in a photograph of Davie's o'the Mill to be keeping chickens.<ref name=Reid/> He regularly appeared on radio programmes, including ''Out with Romany'' and ''Hutman of the BBC''.<ref name=E>Abrams, Page 188</ref> He lived with his wife Cathie in London for two years when he was the secretary of the Vegetarian Society.<ref name=ft/>
A regular visitor to [[Ailsa Craig]], he was known locally as the 'Bird Man' and was an enthusiast for outdoor living, publishing a book entitled ''A Free Man's Philosophy''. He welcomed walkers and cyclists who often camped on his land.<ref name=Reid>Reid (2000), Page 47</ref>
In 1963 Dugald detailed his journey towards Vegetarianism:
''I began rather drastically over 50 years ago [~1910] by cutting out not only all meat or flesh foods, but milk, eggs, butter, tea and coffee. Cheese I have never eaten; indeed I hate the very smell of this decayed milk. Next, I adopted a diet of nuts, fruit, cereals and vegetables. On this Edenic fare I lived for some ten years, and found that my health and strength were greatly improved. […] While I was in London (during World War I), I found it necessary to add some dairy products to my meals, but on returning to Scotland I gradually eliminated these again.''<ref name=VS/>
In later life he lived in a modern cottage and even owned a car.<ref name=L>Abrams, Page 189</ref>
==Fruitarianism== The Fruitarian Society was plagued with disputes over the definition of [[Fruitarian]]ism from as early as 1907. The Scottish Vegetarian Society featured an article in their 1907 journal entitled "Fruitarianism" by Dugald Semple in which he wrote: [[File:Dugald Semple autograph.jpg|thumb|250px|Dugald Semple's autograph]] ''"By fruitarianism is meant a dietary consisting chiefly of nuts and fruits. Cooked cereals and vegetables are not necessarily excluded, although the exclusion of all cooked foods, should means and knowledge permit, will lead to better results. For this dietary it will be noticed that not only is flesh and meat omitted, but also the animal products milk and eggs. The use of these products by vegetarians has long been one of the chief objections to vegetarianism, especially in medical circles".''<ref name=ft/><ref>[http://www.resources.homecall.co.uk/home/page8.html The Fruitarian Society.] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120402161347/http://www.resources.homecall.co.uk/home/page8.html |date=2 April 2012 }} Retrieved : 19 September 2011</ref>
Dugald stated, to make the point about 'Lacto-Vegetarianism' stated that he had never tasted cheese, and therefore it could not be considered as an essential 'binding agent' for body and soul!<ref>[http://ukveggie.com/vegan_news/ Vegan News] Retrieved : 19 September 2011</ref>
In 1912, Dugald stated that he did not believe that milk and eggs were natural foods for man: ''"Eggs were meant to produce chickens and not omelettes; and cow's milk is a perfect food for a calf, but most assuredly not for a grown-up human being."''<ref>[http://www.all-creatures.org/articles/ar-road.pdf No Animal Food] Retrieved : 19 September 2011</ref>
In his 1915 book, ''Joys of the Simple Life'', he wrote an essay entitled 'Alone with Nature', stating that ''"I left off eating flesh-meat and drinking tea ten years ago, and for over eight years have rarely used milk, eggs, salt, sugar, dairy butter, white bread, or condiments of any kind. My health has improved considerably and I have never regretted the change."''
==Influence== ;Committee positions In 1938 Dugald was the President of the Scottish Vegetarian Society (SVS) and Vice-President of the Vegetarian Society.<ref name=SVS/> In 1944 Dugald is recorded as the chairman of the [[Vegan]] Society<ref>[http://www.ivu.org/history/societies/vegansoc.html Vegan Society] Retrieved : 19 September 2011</ref> and vice-president of the International Vegetarian Union.<ref name=VS>[http://www.candidhominid.com/p/vegetarian-history.html Vegetarian Society History] Retrieved : 19 September 2011</ref> In 1953 he was Honorary President of the Scottish Vegetarian Society. In 1954, Dugald was still president of the SVS, one of several Vice-Presidents of IVU.
;Lecture Tours The Victoria Advocate newspaper of Texas reported that he lectured on his beliefs and way of life in the USA, Canada, and America.<ref name=VA>[https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=861&dat=19640120&id=W0ROAAAAIBAJ&sjid=YksDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5619,2036949 Victoria Advocate] Retrieved : 19 September 2011</ref>
From the August 1910 issue of the ''Vegetarian Messenger'' ''"Mr. Dugald Semple, the Scottish apostle of the Simple Life, is arranging lecturing tours for the coming winter. He is prepared to give lectures for a modest fee, and we are sure that his services would be appreciated by vegetarian and allied societies. His address is Wheelhouse, Bridge of Weir, Scotland."''<ref name=SVS>[http://www.ivu.org/history/societies/scottish.html Scottish Vegetarian Society] Retrieved : 19 September 2011</ref> The address appears to refer to his horse drawn caravan that can be seen in the photograph of Davie's o'the Mill.<ref name=Reid/>
; Conferences [[File:Dugald Semple - Title page.jpg|thumb|upright|Title page of 'The Sunfood Way to Health']] Dugald was a delegate from Great Britain to the 1938 10th World Vegetarian Congress held in Norway, attending as President of the Scottish Vegetarian Society and Vice-President of The Vegetarian Society. He delivered a speech on "Vegetarianism and Peace –
''" Mr.Semple said that the question of peace was one of the most important problems with which the various countries of the world were concerned at the present time, and people were naturally interested in what we, as vegetarians, had to offer in place of war and preparations for war. The situation throughout Europe was tragic because war was no longer confined to armed forces but meant the slaughter of innocent women and children. The relation between food and war may come as a surprise to many people, but Socrates pointed out the relationship many years ago. When Plato first outlined the ideal life for his country he suggested that it might be necessary to introduce flesh-foods into his community. Socrates replied by saying that when you introduce flesh-foods it means that you are not going to have sufficient land to grow food and to raise cattle at the same time, and then you will go to your neighbour's territory and cut a slice off his land, and he will object, and then you will go to war with each other. That was the lesson we saw in the last great war and we observe today that many nations which are not self-supporting have a tendency to quarrel with their neighbours.
In Great Britain, before the war, there was only 7.6% of the population living on the land, as against 20% in Belgium, 25% in Holland and 30% in Germany. Today we have only 4.6% of the population in Britain living on the land. It means that the more we get away from nature and congregate people in towns and cities, there is more crime, disease and war. We cannot get away from nature without suffering thereby. We have got to live closer to the laws of our being. We must have a healthy body, but that is not enough. We are suffering today from an unbalanced proportion of activities – we seem to know how to do everything, and yet we do not know how to walk properly. We can link up the world by means of electricity, but we cannot link it up with love and human sympathy. Our attitude towards animals must be completely changed. We must cease to refer to them as "dumb" animals and "livestock." We must remember that they are our co-partners in civilisation.
Vegetarianism is not merely a matter of food reform – it is a philosophy of life, and war will only cease when we cease to live as beasts of prey. So long as we prepare for war we shall get war. We must not only study Darwin but also Kropotkin. Those animals which are carnivorous are becoming less and the vegetarian animals are increasing. Vegetarianism is the first great step. The killing of human beings is akin to the killing of animals and so the exploiting of animal life leads to the selfish exploitation of human beings."''
Dugald quoted Robert Burns, appealing for a more widespread appreciation of the real values in life – more sunshine for the body, more love for the soul, peace for every living creature the world over.<ref name=SVS/>
In 1953, at the 15th World Vegetarian Congress held in India, Dugald stated: ''What a tragedy it would be if Mother India was to become estranged from her sympathy with the rights of animals, which although it may have been carried to extremes, nevertheless has been a noble example to the flesh-eating and vivisecting nations of the West. Yes, let us do our utmost to save India from the soulless materialism of imperialistic nations. Let us show that war and disease are the result of disobedience to spiritual and natural law. That if we harden our hearts against the everyday cruelty off flesh-eating and blood sports, we cannot wonder that the whole; so-called civilised world is preparing for another world catastrophe. East and West must meet if we are to hasten the coming of the New JerusaIem. We go forth to show that science is an affair of the heart as well as the head. That the poor Indian need not live on such a meagre diet, and that we must realise that without love the people perish. The basic error, as Maitra, editor of the Indian journal, once told me, "You people live beside yourself, we live from ourselves. It is only more life in the soul that can unite all people."''<ref>[http://www.ivu.org/congress/wvc57/souvenir/greetings-other.html IVU] Retrieved : 19 September 2011</ref>
In 1955, at the World Vegetarian Congress in Paris, Dugald Semple was listed as a speaker.<ref name=SVS/>
;Individuals [[Morris Krok]], born in Johannesburg, South Africa and whilst seeking solutions for his health problems was influenced by natural healing writers of the 20th century such as Dugald Semple, Vincent Priessnitz, Louis Kuhne, etc.
;Government Civilian rationing began at the end of [[World War I]], on 1 January 1918, with sugar, then meat, butter, and margarine. The Government of the day consulted Dugald and a colleague to educate people concerning how to ration available produce and other food and to propose acceptable substitutes for meat, which had become familiar in their diets.<ref name=SVS/>
;No Stipend League Dugald organised a Scottish 'No Stipend League' against the Church of Scotland's practice of levying a tithe on landowners for the minister's stipend. He was particularly offended because the levy applied to landowners regardless of their faith.<ref>Abram, Page 187</ref>
==Death== In 1953 Dugald wrote, 'Most people do not die, they kill themselves with their knives and forks.'<ref>[https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2507&dat=19531012&id=AUtAAAAAIBAJ&sjid=XoYMAAAAIBAJ&pg=2786,3940448 Glasgow Herald] Retrieved : 19 September 2011</ref>
Dugald Semple died in a nursing home in [[Fairlie, North Ayrshire]] aged 79; the cause of his death was not disclosed.<ref name=ft/><ref name=VA/>
==Published works== * ''Simple Life Visitors.'' Paisley: J & J Cook, printers, 1909. * ''Living in Liberty or The Wheelhouse Philosophy.'' Paisley: Alexander Gardner, 1911. * ''Fruitarianism: a treatise on the diet question.'' Paisley: Alexander Gardner, 1913. * ''Joys of the simple life.'' London: G. Bell, 1915. * ''Simple life recipes: with hints on diet.'' London: C.W.Daniel, c.1915–1919. * ''Life in the open.'' London: G. Bell, 1919. * ''Diet and good health: a popular treatise on the food question.'' London: C.W.Daniel, 1925. * ''Diet in relation to climate.'' London: C.W.Daniel, c.1928. * ''A free man's philosophy.'' London: C.W.Daniel, 1933. * ''An appeal for freedom.'' c.1935. * ''What to eat in war-time,'' with meatless recipes by Cathie Semple. Glasgow: William Maclellan, c.1943. * ''Be your own doctor: natural cures for common ailments.'' Glasgow: William Maclellan, c.1945. Contains details of cures for colds, constipation, how to slim, better eyesight, health from herbs etc. * ''Looking at nature.'' Glasgow: William Maclellan, c.1946. * ''A Scots health cookery book,'' with meatless recipes by Cathie Semple. Glasgow: William Maclellan, 1949. * ''Round Kintyre with Dugald Semple.'' Glasgow: William MacLellan, 1950. * ''Home cures for common ailments. With curative diet.'' Glasgow: William Maclellan, c.1952. * ''The Sunfood Way to Health.'' London: Health for All Publishing Co., 1956. * ''Joy in Living.'' Glasgow: Maclellan, 1957.
