revision.text:
'''Héctor Germán Buitrago Parada''' (January 23, 1968 in Monterrey, [[Casanare Department|Casanare]]), also known as '''Martín Llanos''', and also as '''Patezorro''' or '''Marroco''', is a Colombian right-wing [[Paramilitarism in Colombia|paramilitary]] leader and [[drug lord]]. At the time of his arrest by authorities he was considered the last one of the big paramilitary leaders, as he had been successful in evading capture for years.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.semana.com/nacion/articulo/el-ultimo-jefe-paramilitar/253237-3|title=El último jefe paramilitar|last=Semana|website=El último jefe paramilitar|access-date=2018-06-17}}</ref>
== Biography== By the end of the 1970s his father, Héctor José Buitrago Rodríguez (also known as "El Viejo" or "Tripas"), had assembled a group of cattle-raiser families in the municipalities of Monterrey, in the Casanare department, in the region of Colombia's eastern plains, and provided them with weapons so as to fight against extortion and kidnapping by the [[Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia|FARC]] guerrillas. As this early group, known as "Los Buitragueños," grew up in power and influence it became the basis of the ''Autodefensas Campesinas de Casanare'' (ACC), one of the most powerful [[Paramilitarism in Colombia|paramilitary]] organizations in Colombia. The growth of the organization was supported by the economic and military support provided by drug lord [[José Gonzalo Rodríguez Gacha|Gonzalo Rodríguez Gacha]], going from a group of about 60 individuals to about 500. It has also been suggested that the organization received support from emerald czar [[Víctor Carranza]].<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=https://verdadabierta.com/la-guerra-entre-martin-llanos-y-miguel-arroyave/|title=Carranza entre Martín Llanos y Miguel Arroyave {{!}} Verdad Abierta|date=2013-04-04|work=Verdad Abierta|access-date=2018-06-17|language=es-ES}}</ref> With the death of Rodríguez Gacha in 1989, the ACC became closer to drug trafficking organizations in Venezuela.
Buitrago's father ordered a massacre of eleven members of a judicial commission in 1997, which led to his being arrested in 1998.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.eltiempo.com/archivo/documento/CMS-11118746|title='Martín Llanos', la caída del último gran jefe paramilitar|last=Tiempo|first=Casa Editorial El|website=El Tiempo|language=es-CO|access-date=2018-06-17}}</ref> He was liberated from jail by his sons, Buitrago and his brother Nelson (also known as "Caballo"), but eventually recaptured in 2010.<ref name=":0" /> With his father's arrest, Buitrago took command of the ACC, expanding their military influence as well as their trade with Mexican drug cartels, and its political influence by funding political campaigns.<ref name=":1" /> As the organization grew up in power and influence, however, this growth collided with the interests of the [[United Self-Defense Forces of Colombia|AUC]] paramilitary organization, which the ACC had never joined. The AUC wanted control of the departments of Meta and Casanare and this led to a violent war between the ACC and the Centaurs Bloc of the AUC under the command of paramilitary leaders including [[Miguel Arroyave]] and [[Pedro Oliverio Guerrero|Cuchillo]]. Emerald czar [[Víctor Carranza]] was accused by paramilitary leader Don Mario as being an instigator of the conflict by telling both paramilitary leaders that the other was attempting to kill them.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.elespectador.com/noticias/judicial/articulo171636-denuncian-victor-carranza-fundo-el-paramilitarismo-los-llanos|title=Denuncian que Víctor Carranza fundó el paramilitarismo en los Llanos {{!}} ELESPECTADOR.COM|date=2009-11-11|work=ELESPECTADOR.COM|access-date=2018-06-17|language=es-CO}}</ref><ref name=":2" /> Other sources have suggested instead that [[Víctor Carranza|Carranza]] actually helped the Buitrago side, as he had been long-time friend of Buitrago's father, and pushed local policemen to attack Arroyave's gunmen.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.semana.com/nacion/articulo/victor-carranza-intocable/338973-3|title=Víctor Carranza: el intocable|last=Semana|website=Víctor Carranza el intocable|access-date=2018-06-17}}</ref> Whatever the case, and despite recruiting hundreds of children and teenagers to help with the war, leaving thousands of fatalities behind, the AUC proved superior. This led to Buitrago seeking allegiances with former enemies from the [[Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia|FARC]] guerrilla, particularly commander [[Tomás Medina Caracas|Negro Acacio]], to no avail.<ref name=":0" /> Famously, [[Miguel Arroyave|Arroyave]] seized a golden pistol that had been given to Buitrago as a gift by Mexican drug cartels.
The defeat came at the same time as the AUC were negotiating a peace process with the national government of [[Álvaro Uribe]]. Buitrago decided not to adhere on the grounds of not wanting to be compared with other paramilitary leaders, and because he felt he could be betrayed and even killed as was the case with [[Carlos Castaño Gil|Carlos Castaño]] and even his former enemy [[Miguel Arroyave]]. Buitrago then decided to leave the country, spending time in Costa Rica, Ecuador, Bolivia, and Venezuela.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> While he remained outside of the country, however, his organization regained strength with the assassination of Arroyave and the peace negotiations, and the ACC started regaining control of coca growing lands and drug trafficking routes in Casanare and most of the eastern plains regions.
Buitrago remained relatively anonymous throughout this time, and authorities only had an old picture of him, but after an international operation that involved tracking of Buitrago's wife and mistress they managed to capture him and his brother on February 4, 2012 in the eastern Venezuelan city of Acarigua.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.semana.com/nacion/articulo/asi-captura-martin-llanos/253039-3|title=Así fue la captura de 'Martín Llanos'|last=Semana|website=Así fue la captura de Martín Llanos|access-date=2018-06-17}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-16920933|title=BBC - Error 503 : Service Unavailable|access-date=2018-06-17|language=en-GB}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.insightcrime.org/news/analysis/colombias-last-paramilitary-warlord-captured-in-venezuela/|title=Colombia's Last Paramilitary Warlord Captured in Venezuela|date=2012-02-07|work=InSight Crime|access-date=2018-06-17|language=en-US}}</ref> Buitrago was condemned to 35 years in prison for the assassination of 34 people.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.vanguardia.com/actualidad/colombia/189383-condenan-a-35-anos-de-carcel-a-martin-llanos|title=Condenan a 35 años de cárcel a ‘Martín Llanos’|work=Vanguardia.com|access-date=2018-06-17}}</ref> He was also condemned to 14 years for the murder of Casanare's governor Emiro Sossa in 2001.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.eltiempo.com/archivo/documento/CMS-14343716|title=Condenan a 'Martin Llanos' por crimen de exgobernador de Casanare|last=Tiempo|first=Casa Editorial El|website=El Tiempo|language=es-CO|access-date=2018-06-17}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Buitrago, Hector German}} [[Category:Colombian drug traffickers]] [[Category:Warlords]] [[Category:Colombian people convicted of murder]] [[Category:People convicted of murder by Colombia]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 5 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta10)
revision.text:
'''Ivy Bottini''' (born August 15, 1926 in New York) is an American women's rights and [[LGBT]] rights activist and artist.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=http://www.thelavendereffect.org/projects/ohp/ivy-bottini/|title=Ivy Bottini|date=2014-09-14|work=THE LAVENDER EFFECT®|access-date=2017-05-19|language=en-US}}</ref><ref name="ivybottini">{{cite web|url=http://www.ivybottini.com/2010/bio.html |title=Artist | Activist |publisher=Ivy Bottini |date= |accessdate=2012-11-06}}</ref>
==Personal life== From 1944 until 1947, she attended [[Pratt Institute]] School of Art, where she earned a certificate in advertising graphic design and illustration.<ref name="ivybottini" /> She married Edward Bottini in 1951.<ref name="oac.cdlib">{{cite web|url=http://www.oac.cdlib.org/findaid/ark:/13030/kt6q2nf45f/|title=Finding aid of the Ivy Bottini Papers|date=1926-08-15|publisher=Oac.cdlib.org|accessdate=2012-11-06}}</ref> She was employed for sixteen years at the east coast daily newspaper [[Newsday]], until her move to Los Angeles in 1971.<ref name="ivybottini" />
Bottini realized she had same sex attractions at an early age. Her first crush was on her [[first grade]] female gym teacher. During an interview with the Lavender Effect, Bottini admitted to falling "in love with every gym teacher I ever had in my life." She also formed a close, platonic relationship with one of her seventh grade teachers, whom became a parental figure for her. <ref name=":0" />
Despite her attraction to women, Bottini did not pursue lesbian relationships, due to cultural norms of the time. She was engaged to several men, with each engagement lasting only a few weeks before she'd end the relationship. She married her husband of sixteen years, Eddie, on January 12, 1952.<ref name=":0" /> Leading up to the marriage, Bottini began experiencing physical symptoms involving her ability to swallow food properly. Her doctor realized her symptoms were related to anxiety and referred her to a psychiatrist. She expressed to the psychiatrist that she felt attracted to women, but the psychiatrist told her she was not homosexual. He suggested she abandon her friends and interests and "cleave" to soon to be husband, Eddie.<ref name=":0" /> She did as her psychiatrist instructed, but her lesbian desires did not subside.
Years later, a coworker, Delores Alexander, introduced Bottini to the [[National Organization for Women]] (NOW). Alexander had just interviewed the NOW president [[Betty Friedan]], and felt it would be a useful organization for Bottini to join. Within a month, she had founded the first chapter of NOW in New York City.<ref name=":0" /> Soon after becoming president of the New York chapter of NOW she came out as a lesbian. She left her husband and moved in with a woman in New York City.<ref name="oac.cdlib" /><ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6zRFBGTSgoUC&pg=PA97&dq=ivy+bottini+1968+elected&hl=en&ei=A-HQT7iFOYyD0QHNwP24DQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=book-thumbnail&resnum=1&ved=0CEEQ6wEwAA#v=onepage&q=ivy%20bottini%201968%20elected&f=true|title=Out For Good: The Struggle to Build a Gay Rights Movement in America - Dudley Clendinen, Adam Nagourney - Google Books|date=|publisher=Books.google.com|accessdate=2012-11-06}}</ref>
She also studied acting at [[Lee Strasberg Theatre and Film Institute]] and performed a one-woman show, "The Many Faces of Women", nationwide.<ref name="tenmoregoodyears">{{cite web|url=http://www.tenmoregoodyears.com/page1/page4/page4.html|title=The Cast|date=|publisher=Tenmoregoodyears.com|accessdate=2012-11-06|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130203152813/http://www.tenmoregoodyears.com/page1/page4/page4.html#|archive-date=2013-02-03|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
Bottini now works as a graphic artist.<ref name="bare_url_a">{{cite web|url=http://wehonews.com/z/wehonews/archive/page.php?articleID=31|title=WeHo News|date=|publisher=WeHo News|accessdate=2012-11-06|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120524184049/http://www.wehonews.com/z/wehonews/archive/page.php?articleID=31#|archive-date=2012-05-24|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
== Activism == In 1966, she helped found the New York chapter of the [[National Organization for Women]].<ref name="bare_url">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6zRFBGTSgoUC&pg=PA97&dq=ivy+bottini+1968+elected&hl=en&ei=A-HQT7iFOYyD0QHNwP24DQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=book-thumbnail&resnum=1&ved=0CEEQ6wEwAA#v=onepage&q=ivy%20bottini%201968%20elected&f=false|title=Out For Good: The Struggle to Build a Gay Rights Movement in America - Dudley Clendinen, Adam Nagourney - Google Books|date=|publisher=Books.google.com|accessdate=2012-11-06}}</ref><ref name="laweekly">{{cite web|url=http://www.laweekly.com/2010-05-20/la-life/ivy-bottini-the-beauty-of-seeking-justice/|title=Ivy Bottini: The Beauty of Seeking Justice - Page 1 - LA Life - Los Angeles|date=2010-05-20|publisher=LA Weekly|author=Patrick Range McDonald|accessdate=2012-11-06}}</ref> In 1968, she was elected the president of the New York chapter of the National Organization for Women; she came out as a lesbian later that year.<ref name="oac.cdlib" /><ref name="bare_url" /><ref name="laweekly" /> In 1969, she designed the logo for the National Organization for Women which is still their logo today.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.yourolivebranch.org/2011/06/13/ivy-bottini-merges-activism-and-art-in-designing-dyke-march-t-shirt/|title=Ivy Bottini Merges Activism and Art in Designing Dyke March T-Shirt | Your Olive Branch News - yobo|date=|publisher=News.yourolivebranch.org|author=Jeff Mackler|accessdate=2012-11-06|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120930083023/http://news.yourolivebranch.org/2011/06/13/ivy-bottini-merges-activism-and-art-in-designing-dyke-march-t-shirt/#|archive-date=2012-09-30|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref><ref name="bare_url_a" /> Also in 1969, she held a public forum titled "Is Lesbianism a Feminist Issue?", which was the first time lesbian concerns were introduced into the National Organization for Women.<ref name="bare_url_d">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kpNarH7t9CkC&pg=PA51&dq=1968+lesbian+ivy+bottini&hl=en&ei=4P7QT4ToGcXZ0QHIpdDqDw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=book-thumbnail&resnum=7&ved=0CFoQ6wEwBg#v=onepage&q=1968%20lesbian%20ivy%20bottini&f=false|title=Feminists Who Changed America, 1963-1975 - Google Books|date=2006-09-22|publisher=Books.google.com|accessdate=2012-11-06}}</ref> In 1970, she led a demonstration at the [[Statue of Liberty]] where she and others from the National Organization for Women's New York chapter draped an enormous banner over a railing which read "WOMEN OF THE WORLD UNITE!"<ref name="bare_url_c">{{cite web|url=http://lapride.org/pages07/honorees07.htm|title=Honorees|date=2007-01-04|publisher=Lapride.org|accessdate=2012-11-06|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120906063337/http://lapride.org/pages07/honorees07.htm|archivedate=2012-09-06|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://feminist.org/research/chronicles/fc1970.html|title=The Feminist Chronicles, 1953-1993 - 1970 - Feminist Majority Foundation|date=|publisher=Feminist.org|accessdate=2012-11-06}}</ref> During her time at the National Organization for Women's New York chapter she also introduced feminist consciousness raising, which was later adapted for all chapters in the organization to participate in.<ref name="ivybottini" /> However, later in 1970 [[Betty Friedan]] engineered the expulsion of lesbians from the National Organization for Women's New York chapter, including Ivy Bottini.<ref>Vicki Lynn Eaklor [https://books.google.com/books?id=qJZdHuZ0aM0C&pg=PA145 Queer America: a GLBT history of the 20th century], ABC-CLIO, 2008 {{ISBN|0313337497}} p. 145</ref>
She moved to Los Angeles in 1971.<ref name="ivybottini" /> There she founded AIDS Network LA, the first AIDS organization in Los Angeles, and the Los Angeles Lesbian/Gay Police Advisory Board.<ref name="bare_url_a" /><ref name="tenmoregoodyears" /><ref>[http://news.yourolivebranch.org/2011/06/13/ivy-bottini-merges-activism-and-t-in-designing-dyke-march-t-shirt/]{{dead link|date=November 2012}}</ref> In 1977, she created and hosted the first Lesbian/Gay radio show on a mainstream network (KHJ in Los Angeles.) <ref name="bare_url_a" /> In 1978, she was the Southern California deputy director of the successful campaign against the [[Briggs Initiative]] (No on 6), which would have banned gays and lesbians from teaching in California's public schools. She later chaired the successful No on LaRouche and No on 64 Initiative campaign.<ref name="tenmoregoodyears" /> The Larouche initiative (Number 64), which was not passed, might have quarantined people with AIDS.<ref name="bare_url_b">{{cite web|url=http://westhollywood.patch.com/articles/ivy-bottini-merges-activism-and-art-designs-dyke-march-t-shirt|title=Ivy Bottini Merges Activism and Art in Designing Dyke March T-Shirt - West Hollywood, CA Patch|last=Mills|first=James F.|date=2011-06-10|publisher=Westhollywood.patch.com|accessdate=2012-11-06}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1986-09-21/opinion/op-9036_1_public-health-authorities|title=LaRouche Initiative: Prop 64 Framed for Fear - Los Angeles Times|date=1986-09-21|publisher=Articles.latimes.com|accessdate=2012-11-06}}</ref> In 1981 she was appointed by then-governor [[Jerry Brown]] as Commissioner for "California Commission on Aging", making her the first "out" lesbian or gay person to be appointed to a state board or commission.<ref name="bare_url_a" /> In 1983 she co-founded AIDS Project Los Angeles.<ref name="kcet">{{cite web|url=http://www.kcet.org/socal/local_heroes/lgbt/local-hero-ivy-bottini.html|title=Local Hero: Ivy Bottini | LGBT Pride Month | Local Heroes|date=|publisher=KCET|accessdate=2012-11-06|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121030112501/http://www.kcet.org/socal/local_heroes/lgbt/local-hero-ivy-bottini.html#|archive-date=2012-10-30|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
In 1993, she co-founded the nonprofit organization [[Gay & Lesbian Elder Housing]], which in 2007 developed Triangle Square, the first affordable housing complex for gay and lesbian senior citizens in the country.<ref name="kcet" /> From 1998 until 1999, she co-chaired the addiction and recovery city task force, and established the ad hoc committee City of West Hollywood, to publicize the issue of lesbian and gay partner abuse.<ref name="bare_url_d" />
Also in 1999, she chaired the National Organization for Women's annual national conference, called Pioneer Reunion, in Beverly Hills.<ref name="bare_url_d" /> Shortly after, she co-chaired the Lesbian and Gay Advisory Board for the City of West Hollywood from 2000 to 2010.<ref name="kcet" /> In 2001, she was part of a lesbian and gay rights coalition that formed the [[Alliance for Diverse Community Aging Services]] to help lesbian and gay seniors obtain assisted living and affordable retirement.<ref name="bare_url_d" /> In 2011, she designed t-shirts for the [[Dyke March]] in Los Angeles.<ref name="bare_url_b" />
She and [http://www.thelavendereffect.org The Lavender Effect], an LGBT history organization, are currently advocating for a LGBT museum in Los Angeles.<ref>{{cite web|last=Range |first=Patrick |url=http://blogs.laweekly.com/informer/2012/06/will_there_be_a_world-class_ga.php |title=Will There Be a World-Class Gay and Lesbian Museum in Los Angeles? - Los Angeles - News - The Informer |publisher=Blogs.laweekly.com |date=2012-06-01 |accessdate=2012-11-06}}</ref> She is also advocating for the creation of an AIDS memorial in West Hollywood.<ref name="kcet" />
Her papers and certain audio recordings are held by [[ONE National Gay and Lesbian Archives]].<ref name="oac.cdlib" /> In 2009, the film ''On These Shoulders We Stand'' profiled Ivy Bottini as well as ten other LGBT activists from the early LGBT rights movement in Los Angeles.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://impactstories.org/film.htm|title=On These Shoulders We Stand | Impact Stories Documentary Film|date=|publisher=Impactstories.org|accessdate=2012-11-06}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://westhollywood.patch.com/articles/weho-documentary-shows-how-far-gay-rights-have-come|title=Weho Documentary Shows How Far Gay Rights Have Come - West Hollywood, CA Patch|last=Jacoby|first=Danielle|date=2011-06-30|publisher=Westhollywood.patch.com|accessdate=2012-11-06}}</ref> She participated in an Oral History project by The Lavender Effect, which documented her personal life and work as an acvivist.<ref name=":0" />
== Awards == In 1991, she received Drama Logues' "Best Performance Award" for ''Against the Rising Sea.'' <ref name="bare_url_a" />
In 1998, the [[Ivy Theater]] was established in her honor in West Hollywood.<ref name="bare_url_a" /><ref>{{cite web |url=http://wehonews.com/z/wehonews/archive/page.php?articleID=709 |title=WeHo News |publisher=WeHo News |date=2006-08-26 |accessdate=2012-11-06 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061113072736/http://wehonews.com/z/wehonews/archive/page.php?articleID=709# |archive-date=2006-11-13 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
In 2001, in the [[Matthew Shepard]] Memorial Triangle a tree was planted in her honor, and a plaque placed at the foot of it.<ref name="bare_url_a" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://wehonews.com/z/wehonews/archive/page.php?articleID=68 |title=WeHo News |publisher=WeHo News |date= |accessdate=2012-11-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120227155655/http://wehonews.com/z/wehonews/archive/page.php?articleID=68 |archivedate=2012-02-27 |df= }}</ref>
In 2007, she received the [[Morris Knight|Morris Kight]] Lifetime Achievement Award from Christopher Street West Los Angeles LGBT Pride. <ref name="bare_url_c" />
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Bottini, Ivy}} [[Category:1926 births]] [[Category:American feminists]] [[Category:American women's rights activists]] [[Category:HIV/AIDS activists]] [[Category:Lesbian feminists]] [[Category:LGBT history in New York City]] [[Category:LGBT people from New York (state)]] [[Category:LGBT rights activists from the United States]] [[Category:Living people]]

{{Infobox person |name = James Dolan |image = |alt = |caption = |birth_date = {{Birth date|1981|07|20}} |birth_place = |death_date = {{Death date and age|2017|12|27|1981|07|20}} |death_place = [[Brooklyn]], [[New York (state)|New York]], U.S. |nationality = American |other_names = James S. Dolan
dolanjs |occupation = Computer security expert |years_active = 1999-2017 |education = |employer = |organization = [[Freedom of the Press Foundation]] |known_for = Co-developer of [[SecureDrop]] }} '''James S. Dolan''' (July 20, 1981 – December 27, 2017) was an American [[computer security]] expert who, with [[Aaron Swartz]] and [[Kevin Poulsen]], co-developed [[SecureDrop]], a widely used [[communications security|secure]] digital platform for sources to anonymously submit materials to journalists.{{cite news|last1=Timm|first1=Trevor|title=A tribute to James Dolan, co-creator of SecureDrop, who has tragically passed away at age 36|url=https://freedom.press/news/tribute-james-dolan-co-creator-securedrop-who-has-tragically-passed-away-age-36/|publisher=Freedom of the Press Foundation|date=9 January 2018}} == Early life == Dolan grew up in [[Chester, Orange County, New York|Chester, New York]]. He grew up with four sisters. He went to school at the Tuxedo Park school and was considered gifted at an early age. Later, he moved to Brooklyn, which is where he called home.{{cite news |last=Vincent |first=Isabel |author-link=Isabel Vincent |title=These Hackers' Suicides Are Eerily Similar |date=January 27, 2018 |work=[[New York Post]] |url=https://nypost.com/2018/01/27/these-hackers-suicides-are-eerily-similar/ |access-date=January 28, 2018 |archive-url=https://archive.is/zfahT |archive-date=January 29, 2018 |dead-url=no}} and Chester, NY. == Career == From 1999 to 2006, Dolan served with the [[United States Marine Corps|Marines]] in two deployments during the [[Iraq War]] where he worked as a data network specialist. In 2003, Dolan served with [[III Marine Expeditionary Force]]{{cn|date=January 2018}} during the initial [[Iraq War]]. In his second deployment, which was from September 2004 to March 2005, Dolan served with [[4th Civil Affairs Group]] in [[Fallujah]],{{cn|date=January 2018}} which was one of the centers of [[Fallujah during the Iraq War|the conflict]] at that time. Dolan was in Fallujah during [[Operation Phantom Fury]], part of the [[Second Battle of Fallujah]] Trevor Timm from the [[Freedom of the Press Foundation]] referenced Dolan's military service in his description of Dolan in the obituary he wrote, saying that the impact of serving in Iraq was an often spoke of motivating factor for Dolan's cybersecurity work, with the goal of making metadata "transparent and accountable." After his service in the Iraq War, Dolan worked in computer security at a large IT company.{{cite news|last1=Gilmour|first1=David|title=James Dolan, who co-created SecureDrop, dead at 36|url=https://www.dailydot.com/layer8/james-dolan-dead/|work=[[The Daily Dot]]|date=9 January 2018}} In 2012, as a side project to his IT job, Dolan helped develop the [[Open-source software|open source]] SecureDrop, initially known as DeadDrop.{{cite news|last1=Poulsen|first1=Kevin|title=Strongbox and Aaron Swartz|url=https://www.newyorker.com/news/news-desk/strongbox-and-aaron-swartz|work=[[The New Yorker]]|date=14 May 2013|language=en}} In 2013, Poulsen and Dolan moved it to the [[Freedom of the Press Foundation]] to ensure its continued development and adoption following the death of fellow developer Aaron Swartz.{{cite news|last1=Robinson|first1=Garrett|last2=Dolan|first2=James|title=SecureDrop's Garrett Robinson and James Dolan – at Aaron Swartz Day 2013|url=https://www.aaronswartzday.org/securedrops-garrett-robinson-and-james-dolan-at-aaron-swartz-day-2013/|work=Aaron Swartz Day|date=17 August 2014}}{{cite news|last1=Robinson|first1=Garrett|last2=Dolan|first2=James|title=SecureDrop's Garrett Robinson and James Dolan – at Aaron Swartz Day 2013|url=https://archive.org/details/aaronswartzday2013?start=3477|work=Aaron Swartz Day|date=8 November 2013|format=Video}} Dolan was the lead maintainer for DeadDrop, and as the Freedom of the Press Foundation's first employee, performed outreach and assisted in installations for news organizations that included ''[[The New Yorker]],'' ''[[ProPublica]],'' ''[[The Washington Post]],'' and ''[[VICE News]],'' among others.{{cite news|last1=Timm|first1=Trevor|last2=Reitman|first2=Rainey|title=Freedom of the Press Foundation Launches SecureDrop, an Open-Source Submission Platform for Whistleblowers|url=https://freedom.press/news/freedom-of-the-press-foundation-launches-securedrop-an-open-source-submission-platform-for-whistleblowers/|work=[[Freedom of the Press Foundation]]|date=15 October 2013|format=Press release}}{{cite news|last1=Gustin|first1=Sam|title=Meet SecureDrop, a New Lock Box for Whistleblowers|url=http://business.time.com/2013/10/15/meet-the-nsa-proof-drop-box-for-whistleblowers/|work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|date=15 October 2013}}{{cite news|last1=ssteele|title=Tor at the Heart: SecureDrop|url=https://blog.torproject.org/tor-heart-securedrop|work=[[The Tor Project, Inc|Tor]] Blog|date=6 December 2016|language=en}} In 2015, Dolan moved to [[San Diego]], [[California]] to work as head of security at [[Classy (company)|Classy]], an American software company and an online fundraising platform designed for nonprofit organizations, a position he held at the time of his death. == Death == Dolan was found dead in a Brooklyn hotel in December 2017 at the age of 36.{{cite news|last1=Menegus|first1=Bryan|title=James Dolan, Co-Creator of SecureDrop, Dead at 36|url=https://gizmodo.com/james-dolan-co-creator-of-securedrop-dead-at-36-1821921230|work=[[Gizmodo]]|date=9 January 2018}} Former colleagues speculate James died of suicide (the same fate as Swartz). He reportedly suffered from [[posttraumatic stress disorder|PTSD]] from his time in the Marines. Dolan was the second member of the SecureDrop team to commit suicide. A [[GoFundMe]] fund was set up by his fellow Marines to establish the James Dolan Memorial Fund, which will annually donate to designated non-profit foundations and projects in his name.{{cite web|title=James Dolan Memorial Fund|url=https://www.gofundme.com/james-dolan-memorial-fund|website=[[GoFundMe]]|date=12 January 2018}} == References == {{Reflist|30em}} == External links == * {{Github|dolanjs|James Dolan}} {{Open navbox}} {{Authority Control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Dolan, James}} [[Category:1981 births]] [[Category:2017 deaths]] [[Category:American computer programmers]] [[Category:Computer security specialists]] [[Category:Internet activists]] [[Category:Activists who committed suicide]] [[Category:Male suicides]] [[Category:Programmers who committed suicide]] [[Category:American Marine Corps personnel of the Iraq War]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2014}} {{Use British English|date=January 2014}} {{Infobox scientist | name = Jeremy Marchant Forde | image = Marchant-forde-jeremy.jpg | birth_name=Jeremy Neville Marchant | image_size = | caption = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1966|01|06|df=y}} | birth_place = [[R.A.F. Akrotiri]], Cyprus | death_date = | death_place = | residence = | citizenship = | nationality = British/American | workplaces = [[U.S. Department of Agriculture]] | alma_mater = [[University of Cambridge]] [[University of Bristol]] | thesis_title = The Effects of Dry Sow Housing Conditions on Welfare at Farrowing | thesis_url = http://ulmss-newton.lib.cam.ac.uk/vwebv/holdingsInfo?bibId=18222 | thesis_year = 1994 |ethnicity = |field = {{Plainlist| * [[Ethology]] * [[Animal welfare]]}} |known_for = [[Animal welfare science]] }} '''Jeremy Neville Marchant Forde''', [[Royal Society of Biology|FRSB]] (né '''Marchant'''; born 6 Jan 1966, [[Akrotiri and Dhekelia|R.A.F. Akrotiri]], [[Cyprus]]) is an [[England|English]]/[[Americans|American]] [[biology|biologist]] and Research Animal Scientist at the [[United States Department of Agriculture]] - [[Agricultural Research Service]]'s Livestock Behavior Research Unit, based in West Lafayette, Indiana. He is also a past President of the [[International Society for Applied Ethology]].
Jeremy Marchant Forde attended [[Woodbridge School]] and subsequently the [[University of Bristol]] and [[St. Catharine's College, Cambridge]]. He received his [[Bachelor of Science|BSc]] degree in [[biochemistry]] and [[Doctor of Philosophy|Ph.D.]] degree in applied [[ethology|animal behaviour]] from [[University of Cambridge|Cambridge University]], supervised by Prof. [[Donald Broom]]. During his time as a graduate student, he was a keen sportsman, representing Cambridge in the 1992 and 1993 [[Rugby League Varsity Match]]es,<ref>[https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/rugby-league-breaking-down-the-ancient-barriers-paul-hayward-reports-from-crystal-palace-on-a-varsity-match-without-a-trace-of-snobbery-1496855.html 1993 Rugby League Varsity Match Report] Accessed 15 Nov 2010</ref> winning 2 Half [[Blue (university sport)|Blue]]s and being elected to the [[Hawks' Club]]. In 1996 he received a [[Winston Churchill Memorial Trusts|Churchill Fellowship]] which enabled him to spend 3 months visiting research centers throughout Northern Europe, collating research on alternatives to the farrowing crate, and influencing his work on causes of piglet mortality.<ref>{{cite web|title=Jeremy Marchant|url=http://www.wcmt.org.uk/users/jeremymarchant1996|work=Winston Churchill Memorial Trust|accessdate=18 August 2015}}</ref>
Previous academic positions include Research Associate at the [[University of Cambridge]] and Senior Research Fellow at the [[University of Lincoln]]. Previous academic roles include Honorary Treasurer of the [[International Society for Applied Ethology]] and member of Program Committees for the [[American Society of Animal Science]] and [[British Society of Animal Science]]. He was Chair of the Organizing Committee for the 45th Congress of the [[International Society for Applied Ethology]] held in [[Indianapolis]] in 2011. He has served on the Editorial Board for the [[Journal of Animal Science]] and as a Section Editor for Livestock Science. He is currently a Specialty Chief Editor for [[Frontiers Media|Frontiers in Veterinary Science]], with responsibility for the Animal Behavior & Welfare specialty section.
His early work on the effects of housing systems on the welfare of pregnant sows, specifically on cardiovascular health, bone strength<ref>[http://journals.cambridge.org/abstract_S1357729800014387 Sow Housing and Bone Strength] Accessed 15 Nov 2010</ref> and posture-changing behavior, contributed to the body of evidence that led, eventually, to major changes in animal welfare and the way these animals are kept in many parts of the world, beginning with the European Union and spreading to North America and Oceania. He was also the first animal welfare scientist to publish a study using [[heart rate variability]] as a welfare indicator.<ref>{{cite journal|url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0168159197000221 | doi=10.1016/S0168-1591(97)00022-1 | volume=55 | title=The effects of housing on heart rate of gestating sows during specific behaviours | year=1997 | journal=Applied Animal Behaviour Science | pages=67–78 | last1 = Marchant | first1 = Jeremy N. | last2 = Rudd | first2 = Andrew R. | last3 = Broom | first3 = Donald M.}}</ref>
He is a cousin of the cricketer [[Michael Peck (cricketer)|Michael Peck]].
== Awards == * 1996: Travelling Fellowship: [[Winston Churchill Memorial Trusts]] * 1999: Distinguished Junior Scholar: [[Peter Wall Institute for Advanced Studies]], University of British Columbia.<ref>[https://pwias.ubc.ca/sites/default/files/annualreport/pdf/ar-99-00.pdf Junior Scholars - Peter Wall Institute for Advanced Studies] Accessed 10 Jul 2018</ref> * 2002–2016: 14 Certificates of Merit: US Department of Agriculture
== Selected works == * ''[[The Welfare of Pigs]]'' (2009) * ''[[The Encyclopedia of Applied Animal Behaviour and Welfare]]'', with [[Daniel Mills - Applied Ethologist|Daniel S. Mills]], Paul McGreevy, David Morton, Christine Nicol, Clive Phillips, Peter Sandoe and Ronald Swaisgood (2010) * ''[[Proceedings of the 45th Congress of the International Society for Applied Ethology]]'', with Edmond Pajor (2011)
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [https://www.ars.usda.gov/people-locations/person?person-id=24640 USDA-ARS, LBRU] * [http://www.applied-ethology.org/ International Society for Applied Ethology] * [http://www.ars.usda.gov/meetings/ISAE2011/ 45th Congress of the ISAE, 2011]
{{authority control}}

{{Infobox person | name = Jordan Scott Cronenweth | image = | imagesize = | caption = | birthname = | birth_date = {{birth date|1935|02|20}} | birth_place = [[Los Angeles, California]], U.S. | death_date = {{death date and age|1996|11|29|1935|02|20}} | death_place = Los Angeles, California, U.S. | occupation = [[Cinematographer]] | yearsactive = 1969–1992 | known_for = ''[[Blade Runner]]''
''[[Altered States]]''
''[[Peggy Sue Got Married]]'' | spouse = | children = [[Jeff Cronenweth]] | parents = | awards = * [[BAFTA Award for Best Cinematography|BAFTA Film Award for Best Cinematography]] * [[American Society of Cinematographers|ASC Award for Outstanding Cinematography]] * [[Los Angeles Film Critics Association|LAFCA Award for Best Cinematography]] | }} '''Jordan Scott Cronenweth''' (February 20, 1935 – November 29, 1996) was an American [[cinematographer]] based in Los Angeles, California. He was a member of the [[American Society of Cinematographers]] (ASC). His son, [[Jeff Cronenweth]], is also a cinematographer and an active member of said organization. A contemporary of [[Conrad L. Hall|Conrad Hall]], he was recognized for his distinctive style of heavily textured, ''[[film noir]]''-inspired photography, seen in numerous classic films, including ''[[Zandy's Bride]]'', ''[[Gable and Lombard]]'', ''[[Altered States]],'' and ''[[Peggy Sue Got Married]]''. He is perhaps best remembered for his [[BAFTA Award for Best Cinematography|BAFTA Award]]-winning work on the groundbreaking [[science fiction film]] ''[[Blade Runner]],''Lightman, Herb A. and Richard Patterson (March 1999). [http://www.theasc.com/magazine/mar99/blade/ Cinematography for Blade Runner.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928010609/http://www.theasc.com/magazine/mar99/blade/ |date=2007-09-28 }} ''American Cinematographer'' which is credited as codifying the [[cyberpunk]] aesthetic, and is lauded by some as among the best cinematography of all-time.{{Cite web|url=https://theasc.com/magazine/mar99/blade/pg1.htm|title=Cinematography for Blade Runner - page 1|website=theasc.com|access-date=2017-09-20}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.diyphotography.net/blade-runner-cinematography-jordan-cronenweth/|title=Blade Runner: The Cinematography of Jordan Cronenweth|date=2014-04-17|work=DIY Photography|access-date=2017-09-20|language=en-US}} He was nominated for an [[Academy Award for Best Cinematography]] and received an [[American Society of Cinematographers Award for Outstanding Achievement in Cinematography in Theatrical Releases|ASC Award for Outstanding Achievement in Cinematography in Theatrical Releases]], and he is widely considered one of the most influential cinematographers of all time.{{Cite news|url=http://www.diyphotography.net/blade-runner-cinematography-jordan-cronenweth/|title=Blade Runner: The Cinematography of Jordan Cronenweth|date=2014-04-17|work=DIY Photography|access-date=2017-09-07|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.creativeplanetnetwork.com/news/news-articles/icg-announces-top-10-influential-cinematographers/415189|title=ICG Announces Top 10 Influential Cinematographers|date=2014-06-09|work=Creative Planet Network|access-date=2017-09-07|language=en|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170907082404/http://www.creativeplanetnetwork.com/news/news-articles/icg-announces-top-10-influential-cinematographers/415189|archive-date=2017-09-07|dead-url=yes|df=}} == Life and career == Born in Los Angeles, California on February 20, 1935, Cronenweth attended [[North Hollywood High School]] and later [[Los Angeles City College]], majoring in Engineering. While in college he interned as a [[Film laboratory|film lab assistant]] at [[Columbia Pictures]] acted as a cameraman on the 1955 musical film [[Oklahoma! (1955 film)|''Oklahoma!'']].{{Cite web|url=http://www.cinematographers.nl/GreatDoPh/cronenwethjordan.htm|title=JORDAN CRONENWETH|website=www.cinematographers.nl|access-date=2017-09-07}} Cronenweth was diagnosed with [[Parkinson's disease]] in 1978. He continued working despite pain for 13 years. His widely acclaimed{{Cite web|url=http://ohmycinema.blogspot.com/p/blade-runner.html|title="Oh, My...." Cinematography: Blade Runner|website="Oh, My...." Cinematography|access-date=2017-09-07}}{{Cite news|url=http://evanerichards.com/2009/1358|title=The Cinematography of "Blade Runner" (1982) – Evan E. Richards|date=2009-07-23|work=Evan E. Richards|access-date=2017-09-07|language=en-US}} work on the iconic science fiction-noir ''[[Blade Runner]]'' won the Best Cinematography Award from the [[Los Angeles Film Critics Association]] and got a [[British Society of Cinematographers|BSC Award]] nomination and [[BAFTA Award|BAFTA Film Award]]. He won a 1987 [[American Society of Cinematographers|ASC]] Award and earned an [[Academy Award for Best Cinematography|Academy Award]] nomination for ''[[Peggy Sue Got Married]]''. Cronenweth was initially hired as the director of photography for the film ''[[The Adventures of Buckaroo Banzai Across the 8th Dimension]]'' but halfway through production producers replaced him with [[Fred J. Koenekamp]].{{cite web|url=http://www.movieline.com/2011/01/26/jeff-cronenweth-on-his-oscar-nomination-for-the-social-network-and-joining-his-father-as-a-nominee/|title=Jeff Cronenweth on His Oscar Nomination for The Social Network and Joining His Late Father as a Nominee|last=Ryan|first=Mike|date=2011-01-26|publisher=Movieline.com|accessdate=2012-04-01}} He was also replaced two weeks into the production of ''[[Alien 3|Alien³]]'' after falling ill, and died in 1996 at the age of 61.Staff report (December 25, 1996). Memorial Service Set for Cronenweth. ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' Cause of death was Parkinson's disease. A 2003 poll of his peers conducted by the International Cinematographers Guild placed Cronenweth among the ten most influential cinematographers of all time.Staff report (October 17, 2003). Cinematographers pick their Top 11. ''[[Los Angeles Times]]''[http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Top+10+Most+Influential+Cinematographers+Voted+on+by+Camera+Guild.-a0108995062 "Top 10 Most Influential Cinematographers Voted on by Camera Guild," October 16, 2003.] Retrieved January 28, 2011. == Personal life == He and his first wife Carol had three children, Christie Cronenweth, Tim Cronenweth, and two-time [[Academy Award for Best Cinematography|Oscar]]-nominated cinematographer [[Jeff Cronenweth]].http://www.empireonline.com/features/cinematographers/19.asp He was later married to Shane Cronenweth. == Filmography == {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Year ! Title !Director ! class="unsortable" | Notes |- |1969 |[[Trilogy (film)|''Trilogy'']] |[[Frank Perry]] |"A Christmas Memory" segment with [[Joseph C. Brun]] and [[Conrad Hall]] |- |1970 |''[[Brewster McCloud]]'' |[[Robert Altman]] |with [[Lamar Boren]] |- |1971 |''[[The Touch of Satan]]'' |Don Henderson | |- | rowspan="2" |1972 |''[[Cry for Me, Billy]]'' |[[William Graham (director)|William A. Graham]] | |- |[[Play It as It Lays (film)|''Play It as It Lays'']] |Frank Perry | |- |1973 |[[Birds of Prey (1973 film)|''Birds of Prey'']] |William A. Graham |Television film |- | rowspan="3" | 1974 |''[[The Nickel Ride]]'' |[[Robert Mulligan]] | |- |''[[Zandy's Bride]]'' |[[Jan Troell]] | |- |[[The Front Page (1974 film)|''The Front Page'']] |[[Billy Wilder]] | |- |1976 |''[[Gable and Lombard]]'' |[[Sidney J. Furie]] | |- | rowspan="3" |1977 |''[[One in a Million: The Ron LeFlore Story]]'' |William A. Graham |Television film |- |[[Handle with Care (1977 film)|''Handle with Care'']] |[[Jonathan Demme]] | |- |[[Rolling Thunder (film)|''Rolling Thunder'']] |[[John Flynn (director)|John Flynn]] | |- |1980 |''[[Altered States]]'' |[[Ken Russell]] | |- |1981 |''[[Cutter's Way]]'' |[[Ivan Passer]] | |- | rowspan="2" |1982 |[[Best Friends (1982 film)|''Best Friends'']] |[[Norman Jewison]] | |- |''[[Blade Runner]]'' |[[Ridley Scott]] | * Won: [[BAFTA Award for Best Cinematography]] [[Los Angeles Film Critics Association Awards|LAFCA Award for Best Cinematography]] [[New York Film Critics Circle|NYFCC Award for Best Cinematography]] * Nominated for: [[British Society of Cinematographers|BSC Award for Best Cinematography]] |- | rowspan="2" |1984 |''[[Stop Making Sense]]'' |Jonathan Demme |[[Concert film]] |- |''[[The Adventures of Buckaroo Banzai Across the 8th Dimension]]'' |[[W. D. Richter]] |with [[Fred J. Koenekamp]] |- | rowspan="2" |1986 |''[[Just Between Friends]]'' |[[Allan Burns]] | |- |''[[Peggy Sue Got Married]]'' |[[Francis Ford Coppola]] | * Won: [[ASC Award for Outstanding Achievement in Cinematography in Theatrical Releases|ASC Award for Outstanding Achievement in Cinematography]] * Nominated for: [[Academy Award for Best Cinematography]] |- |1987 |''[[Gardens of Stone]]'' |Francis Ford Coppola | |- |1988 |''[[U2: Rattle and Hum]]'' |[[Phil Joanou]] |Concert film |- |1990 |[[State of Grace (1990 film)|''State of Grace'']] |Phil Joanou | |- |1991 |[[Get Back (film)|''Get Back'']] |[[Richard Lester]] |Concert film |- |1992 |''[[Final Analysis]]'' |Phil Joanou |Final film |} == Awards & nominations == === Academy Awards === * Nominated: [[Academy Award for Best Cinematography]]; ''[[Peggy Sue Got Married]]'' (1986) === BAFTA Awards === * Won: [[BAFTA Award for Best Cinematography]]; ''[[Blade Runner]]'' (1982) === ASC Awards === * Won: [[ASC Award for Outstanding Achievement in Cinematography in Theatrical Releases]]; ''[[Peggy Sue Got Married]]'' (1986) === BSC Awards === * Nominated: [[British Society of Cinematographers|BSC Award for Best Cinematography]]; ''[[Blade Runner]]'' (1982) === Los Angeles Film Critics Association Awards === * Won: [[Los Angeles Film Critics Association|LAFC Award for Best Cinematography]]; ''[[Blade Runner]]'' (1982) === New York Film Critics Circle === * Won: [[New York Critic's Circle Award|NYCC Award]]; ''[[Blade Runner]]'' (1982) ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{IMDb name|id=0005675|title=Jordan Cronenweth}} *[http://brmovie.com/Profiles/BR_Maker_Cronenweth.htm BRmovie.com] – Jordan Cronenweth Profile {{Navboxes | title = Awards for Jordan Cronenweth | list = {{American Society of Cinematographers Theatrical Release Award}} {{BAFTA Award for Best Cinematography}} }} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Cronenweth, Jordan}} [[Category:1935 births]] [[Category:1996 deaths]] [[Category:American cinematographers]] [[Category:BAFTA winners (people)]] [[Category:People from Los Angeles]] [[Category:People with Parkinson's disease]]

'''Keith DeRose''' (born April 24, 1962) is an [[American philosopher]] teaching at [[Yale University]] in [[New Haven, Connecticut]],<ref>[http://www.yale.edu/philos/people/derose_keith.html Faculty Page at Yale University]</ref> where he is currently Allison Foundation Professor of Philosophy. He taught previously at [[New York University]] and [[Rice University]]. His primary interests include [[epistemology]], [[philosophy of language]], [[philosophy of religion]], and history of modern philosophy. He is best known for his work on [[contextualism]] in epistemology, especially as a response to the traditional problem of [[skepticism]].<ref>Michael Williams, "Knowledge, Reflection and Sceptical Hypotheses", Erkenntnis '''61''' (2004)</ref>
==Education== DeRose graduated from [[Calvin College]] in 1984 with a [[Bachelor of Arts|B.A.]] in Philosophy. He then studied at [[UCLA]], earning an [[Master of Arts|M.A.]] in 1986 and a [[Doctor of Philosophy|PhD]] in 1990; his dissertation was entitled ''Knowledge, Epistemic Possibility, and Skepticism'', under [[Rogers Albritton]]. While at UCLA, he won the Robert M. Yost Prize for Excellence in Teaching (1988), was awarded the Griffin Fellowship in 1990, and won the Carnap Essay Prize in 1989 and again in 1990.
==Selected publications== *''The Case for Contextualism. Knowledge, Skepticism, and Context'', Oxford University Press, 2009. *"The Ordinary Language Basis for Contextualism and the New Invariantism," The Philosophical Quarterly, 2005. *"Direct Warrant Realism," in A. Dole and A. Chignell, ed., ''God and the Ethics of Belief: New Essays in Philosophy of Religion'' (Cambridge University Press, 2005). *"Single Scoreboard Semantics," Philosophical Studies, 2004. *"Assertion, Knowledge, and Context," Philosophical Review, 2002; Philosopher's Annual, vol. 26. *"Solving the Skeptical Problem," Philosophical Review, 1995; Philosopher's Annual, vol. 18. *"Contextualism and Knowledge Attributions," Philosophy and Phenomenological Research, 1992 *"Epistemic Possibilities," Philosophical Review, 1991. *"Reid's Anti-Sensationalism and His Realism," Philosophical Review, 1989.
==See also== * [[American philosophy]] * [[List of American philosophers]]
==References== <references/>
==External links== *[http://pantheon.yale.edu/~kd47 Personal homepage] *[http://pantheon.yale.edu/%7Ekd47/CV.htm C.V.] *[http://pantheon.yale.edu/~kd47/e-page.htm Epistemology Homepage]
{{Authority control}}

{{Infobox saint |name= Saints Leontius, Hypatius and Theodolus |birth_date= |death_date=~70-79 AD |feast_day= 18 June |venerated_in= [[Coptic Orthodox Church]], [[Eastern Orthodox Church]], [[Roman Catholic Church]] |image= |imagesize= 250px |caption= |birth_place= |death_place=[[Tripoli]] |titles= [[Christian martyrs|Martyrs]] |beatified_date= |beatified_place= |beatified_by= |canonized_date=Pre-congregation |canonized_place= |canonized_by= |attributes= |patronage=[[Syria]] |major_shrine= |suppressed_date= |issues= }} '''Saints Leontius, Hypatius and Theodolus''' were [[Roman soldiers]] who, according to [[Christian]] tradition, were [[martyr]]ed for their faith.
Leontius was [[Greece|Greek]] by origin, and served as an officer of the imperial army in the [[Phoenicia]]n city of [[Tripoli, Lebanon|Tripoli]] during the reign of [[Vespasian]] (70-79). Leontius was distinguished for his bravery and good sense, and the people of Tripoli held him in deep respect because of his virtue.
The emperor appointed the Roman senator [[Adrian (Roman governor)|Adrian]] as governor of the Phoenician district, with full powers to hunt out [[Christians]], and in case of their refusal to offer sacrifice to the [[Roman gods]], to give them over to torture and death. On his way to Phoenicia, Adrian received a report that Leontius had turned many away from worshipping the [[pagan god]]s. The governor sent the [[tribune]] Hypatius with a detachment of soldiers to Tripoli so as to find and arrest the Christian Leontius. Along the way the tribune Hypatius fell seriously ill, and being near death, he saw in a dream an angel, which said: "If you wish to be healed, you and your soldiers should say three times: 'God of Leontius, help me.'".
Opening his eyes Hypatius beheld the angel and said, "I was sent to arrest Leontius, how is it that I should appeal to his God?" At this moment the angel became invisible. Hypatius told his dream to the soldiers, among whom was his friend Theodolus, and all of them together asked for help from the God whom Leontius confessed. Hypatius was immediately healed, to the great joy of his soldiers, but only Theodolus sat aside, pondering the miracle. His soul was filled with love for God, and he told Hypatius to proceed twice as quickly to the city in search of St Leontius.
Upon their arrival in the city, a stranger met them and invited them to his house, where he lavishly hosted the travelers. Learning that their hospitable host was St Leontius, they fell on their knees and asked him to enlighten them with faith in the True God. They were baptized there, and when Leontius prayed over them calling on the Name of the Most Holy Trinity, a luminous cloud overshadowed the newly baptized and poured forth rain. The remaining soldiers in search of their commander arrived in Tripoli, where the governor Adrian had also arrived. Learning what had happened, he order Leontius, Hypatius and Theodolus to be brought to him. After threatening them with torture and death, he demanded that they renounce Christ and offer sacrifice to the Roman gods.
All three firmly confessed their faith in Christ. Hypatius was put under a column and raked with iron claws, and Theodolus was mercilessly beaten with rods. Seeing the steadfastness of these saints, they beheaded them. After torture, they sent Leontius to prison. In the morning he came before the governor. Adrian tried to entice him with honors and rewards, but accomplishing nothing, he gave him over to new tortures. Leontius was suspended head downwards from a pillar with a heavy stone about his neck, but nothing could make him renounce Christ. The governor gave orders to beat the sufferer with rods until he died. They then threw Leontius' body outside the city, but Christians reverently buried it near Tripoli.
The deaths of these martyrs occurred between 70-79. The accusation against St. Leontius and his sufferings and death are recorded on tin tablets prepared by the court scribe (commentarisius). These tablets were placed at the grave.
==Veneration== A [[cathedral]] at [[Bosra]] was dedicated to Leontius and he was the [[patron saint]] of [[Syria]].<ref>Saints of June 18: [http://www.saintpatrickdc.org/ss/0618.shtml#hypa Leontius, Hypatius (Ipazio), and Theodolus]</ref>
==External links== <references/>
{{authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Leontius, Hypatius And Theodolus}} [[Category:1st-century deaths]] [[Category:Saints from Roman Greece]] [[Category:Saints trios]] [[Category:Angelic visionaries]] [[Category:1st-century Christian martyrs]] [[Category:Year of birth unknown]] [[Category:Groups of Christian martyrs of the Roman era]] [[Category:Military saints]]

{{Multiple issues| {{refimprove|date=July 2009}} {{cleanup|date=July 2009}} }}
The '''Camp Kill Yourself Crew''' (referred to as '''The CKY Crew''') was a group of friends and relatives centered around [[Bam Margera]], many of whom are from or located in and around [[West Chester, Pennsylvania]]. The crew was active from [[CKY (video series)|Landspeed presents: CKY]] (1999) to [[Minghags]] (2009). Some members of the crew were skateboarders, while others were involved either on-camera or behind-the scenes in Margera's various projects such as the [[CKY (videos)|CKY Videos]], ''[[Jackass (TV series)|Jackass]]'', ''[[Viva La Bam]]'', ''[[Haggard: The Movie]]'', ''[[Bam's Unholy Union]]'' and [[Radio Bam]].
The CKY Crew was closely linked to the band [[CKY (band)|CKY]], which features Bam's brother, Jess Margera, on drums. Music by the band was often featured in video projects members of the crew were involved with.
In 2011, a few members of the crew briefly reunited for [[MTV]]'s Tribute to the late [[Ryan Dunn]]. [[Bam Margera]], [[Jess Margera]], [[Rake Yohn]] and [[Chris Raab]] were all featured in the special.
On November 2, 2014, [[MTV]] aired a special called ''CKY: The Greatest Hits''. It featured new interviews with [[Bam Margera]], [[Jess Margera]], [[Rake Yohn]], [[Chris Raab]], [[April Margera]], [[Phil Margera]], Dave Battaro and [[Joe Frantz]]. With special appearances from [[Johnny Knoxville]], [[Jeff Tremaine]], [[Kerry Getz]] and Tim O'Connor. The special also featured unreleased footage documenting the series as a whole. The special was directed by longtime CKY Crew member and cinematographer [[Joe Frantz]].<ref>http://www.mtv.com/videos/misc/1094793/cky-the-greatest-hits-sneak-peek.jhtml</ref> ==Main Crew== *[[Bam Margera]] *[[Brandon DiCamillo]] – Was responsible for the Shopping Carts skit and wrote all the skits and stunts with Margera while making the CKY videos. DiCamillo was known for playing various characters in movies and in the CKY videos. He was one of the groomsmen at Margera's wedding. After 2009's ''Minghags'', DiCamillo has not appeared in any CKY related project. It is believed he had a falling out with Margera. *[[Ryan Dunn]] – Dunn was part of both the CKY and Jackass crews. He and Margera participated in the [[Gumball 3000]] three times in the years 2005, 2006 and 2008. Dunn also starred in Margera's directorial debut, ''Haggard: The Movie''. Dunn died in a drunk-driving incident on June 20, 2011.[2] *[[Chris Raab]] (aka Raab Himself) – Appeared in all of the CKY videos. Raab left the crew shortly after the filming of ''Viva La Bam'' in 2006 after having a dispute with Margera for unknown reasons. He released his movie ''Hotdog Casserole'' in 2008. Raab made his most recent appearance in MTV's "A Tribute to Ryan Dunn" alongside Margera in 2011. *[[Rake Yohn]] (real name Edward Webb) – Known for his long hair, love for metal, and strong dislike of mustard. He is also a chemist after receiving his BS at Penn State. Alongside DiCamillo, he co-hosted the show ''Blastazoid''. They also both appear in Raab's movie ''Hotdog Casserole''.
==The Margeras== *[[April Margera]] – Bam's mother *[[Phil Margera]] – Bam's father *[[Boof Margera]] – Bam's step aunt *[[Vincent Margera]] – a.k.a. "Don Vito". Bam's uncle. He died of liver and kidney failure on November 15, 2015. *[[Jess Margera]] – Bam's brother. He plays drums for [[CKY (band)|CKY]], [[Gnarkill]], [[Viking Skull]], and [[The Company Band]]. Jess was Bam's [[groomsman|best man]] at his wedding. *'''Darlene Margera''' – a.k.a. "Mum-Mum" or "Mom-Mom". She is Phil and Vincent's mother, April's mother-in-law and the grandmother of Jess and Bam Margera. She made a few appearances on Viva La Bam, Bam's Unholy Union and in the CKY Videos. She died in 2007. *'''Phillip "Pop-Pop" Margera Sr.'''<ref>Confirmed first name on the Minghags website</ref> – The father of Phil Margera and Don Vito. Appeared in Viva La Bam, Bam's Unholy Union, ''Haggard: The Movie'' and ''Minghags: The Movie''. He is credited for giving Brandon Margera the "Bam" nickname.
==Others== *'''Dave Battaro''' – a.k.a. Lord Battaro. He and DiCamillo roomed together before. He played the "Mustard Man" in CKY4. *'''Matt Cole''' – a.k.a. "Shitbird". Bam's uncle on April's side. Plays guitar for [[Gnarkill]]. Has appeared in [[Bam's Unholy Union]]. Is on [[Radio Bam]] regularly. He was one of the groomsmen in Bam's wedding. He also appeared in "Where The #$&% is Santa?" *'''Dave Decurtis''' – a.k.a. Naked Dave. He appears in Margera's works naked (hence the nickname). A stunt of him running naked in front of a van was featured on [[Jackass (TV Show)|Jackass]] and originally appeared on CKY. He usually has clothes on only when not filiming, he is often compared to Nudie Novak. *'''[[Jason Ellis (radio host)|Jason Ellis]]''' – Pro-skater. He has appeared in [[Viva La Bam]] and ''[[Haggard: The Movie]]''. He had a show on [[SpikeTV]] called The Wild World of Spike, currently the host of the Jason Ellis Show. *'''[[Joe Frantz]]''' – Under Bam's direction, [[Joe Frantz]] has served multiple roles as Producer and Director Of Photography on the independent films [[Haggard: The Movie|Haggard]] and [[Minghags]], the [[CKY (video series)|CKY]] Video Series (CKY3 and CKY4), and music videos for [[HIM (Finnish band)|HIM]], [[CKY (band)|CKY]], [[The 69 Eyes]] (as well as other popular bands). Frantz is also one of the cameramen behind [[Jackass 2]], [[Jackass 2.5]], and [[Jackass 3D]]. He was also in the show [[Blastazoid]] with Rake Yohn and Brandon DiCamillo. Frantz is known for the on-screen appearances he has made in the works he produces, in television shows and films such as [[MTV]]'s [[Viva La Bam]], [[Bam's Unholy Union]], the CKY Video Series, and [[Bam Margera Presents: Where the#$&% Is Santa?]]. He also is a collaborative coauthor of the book [[Dreamseller]], which he wrote with [[MTV]]/Jackass personality [[Brandon Novak]]. *'''Ryan Gee''' – a.k.a. "Shitgoose", "The Gill". He is a professional photographer who works with Bam on many of his projects including the behind-the-scenes footage for "Minghags". *[[Kerry Getz]] – Pro-skater known for his tantrums while skateboarding, which is why on the first CKY video he is nicknamed ' Hockey Temper'. *[[Chad I. Ginsburg]]- CKY's guitarist. He was one of the groomsmen at Bam's wedding. Operates the soundboard on [[Radio Bam]]. He also appeared in Bam's Unholy Union and Where the #$&% is Santa. *'''Chris and Mark Hanna''' – Brothers. Chris is involved with Bam's work and managed [[CKY (band)|CKY]] on the Viva La Bands tour. They both used to be neighbors with the Margera's. Mark was good friends with Bam and appears in CKY 3, the CKY Documentary, Haggard: The Movie, Viva La Bam, Minghags and Where the #$&% is Santa. Mark has also been a drum tech for CKY on various tours. *[[Tony Hawk]] – a.k.a. Birdman. Professional skateboarding legend. Has made several appearances on Viva La Bam. *[[Terry Kennedy (skateboarder)|Terry Kennedy]] – a.k.a. Compton Ass Terry. Professional skateboarder. He appeared on Viva La Bam and appeared in Minghags. *'''Mike Maldonado''' -Professional skater who has appeared in the CKY videos. *[[Deron Miller]] – Ex CKY singer / guitarist. Has appeared off and on in Bam's projects. He is married to [[Felissa Rose]], star of the horror movie [[Sleepaway Camp]], which CKY used a screenshot from for the album artwork of their Disengage The Simulator EP and other merchandise. They have three children together. *'''Tim Glomb''' – A skilled carpenter and construction worker with a knack for skateboard park building. He made several appearances in the first few seasons of Viva la Bam and towards the end had become a regular. During Viva la Bam in the first episode he built skateboarding ramps all over the interior and exterior of Bam's house. He is credited on "Where The #$&% is Santa" for helping with the story. He now splits his time between [[Denver]], [[Colorado]] and Pennsylvania. *[[Brandon Novak]] – Former pro-skater & Bam's childhood friend. Appeared in Haggard as a drug dealer while battling his own addictions. The documentary for Haggard ended up being about him and Ryan Dunn confronting him about it. He was a regular on Bam's Unholy Union and was one of Bam's Grooms men. He has small roles in Bam's other projects as well including Jackass and Minghags. *'''Tim O'Connor''' – He has appeared in many episodes of Viva La Bam. He has also appeared in the CKY videos. Tim was a MADE coach on MTV's ''[[Made (TV series)|Made]]. *[[Mike Vallely]] – Professional skateboarder. He appeared in a several CKY movies and Viva La Bam episodes. *'''Art Webb''' – Rake Yohn's brother. He is credited as "Art Webb 1986" because of his love for music in that particular year. Art's longest known speaking part comes in an unscripted tirade in the documentary in the ''[[Haggard: The Movie]]'' bonus features when he professes his willingness to act as [[Tony Hawk]]'s bodyguard. He now runs a podcast called "Gamecasa". Art also played a speaking role in the video game "Trials 2" along with Brandon and Rake. *[[CKY (band)|Vernon Zaborowski]]- Former Bass Player for CKY. He was featured briefly in the [[CKY (video series)|CKY]] video series. Vern briefly reunited with the band to perform one song at the [[San Jose, California|San Jose]] stop of [[Warped Tour 2017]].
==CKY Crew Filmography==
===Movies===

|- |''[[Haggard: The Movie]]'' |- |2006 |''[[Jackass Number Two]]'' |[[Bam Margera]], [[Ryan Dunn]], [[Brandon Dicamillo]] (Cameo), [[Rake Yohn]] (Cameo) |- |2007 |''[[Jackass 2.5]]'' |[[Bam Margera]], [[Ryan Dunn]], [[Brandon Dicamillo]], [[Rake Yohn]] |- |2009 |''[[Minghags: The Movie]]'' |[[Bam Margera]], [[Ryan Dunn]], [[Brandon Dicamillo]], [[Rake Yohn]] |- |2010 |''[[Jackass 3D]]'' |[[Bam Margera]], [[Ryan Dunn]], [[Rake Yohn]] (Cameo) |- |2011 |''[[Jackass 3.5]]'' |[[Bam Margera]], [[Ryan Dunn]] |- |}

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2017}}
The following is a list of notable people who are listed or reported to be dyslexic, or who some people thought were dyslexic, or more generally whenever there is an urban legend or popular myth about their being dyslexic. <!-- Note: Please cite sources when adding entries to this list, non sourced entries will be removed-->
[[File:Alexander Graham Bell.jpg|thumb|right|100px|[[Alexander Graham Bell|Bell]]]] [[File:Butler_signing.jpg|thumb|right|100px|[[Octavia E. Butler|Butler]]]] [[File:LewisCarrollSelfPhoto.jpg|thumb|right|100px|[[Lewis Carroll|Carroll]]]] [[File:Cher_-_Casablanca.jpg|thumb|right|100px|[[Cher]]]] [[File:Albert_Einstein_Head.jpg|thumb|right|100px|[[Albert Einstein|Einstein]]]] [[File:Pierre Curie by Dujardin c1906.jpg|thumb|right|100px|[[Pierre Curie|Curie]]]] [[Image:Faraday-Millikan-Gale-1913.jpg|right|thumb|100 px|[[Michael Faraday|Faraday]]]] [[Image:Justus Sustermans - Portrait of Galileo Galilei, 1636.jpg|right|thumb|100 px|[[Galileo Galilei|Galilei]]]] [[File:Karina Galvez - Ecuadorian Poet.jpg|thumb|right|100px|[[Karina Galvez|Galvez]]]] [[File:Salma_Hayek_2,_2012.jpg|thumb|right|100px|[[Salma Hayek|Hayek]]]] [[File:Mark_Henry_WWE_Axxess_2014.jpg|thumb|right|100px|[[Mark Henry|Henry]]]] [[File:Jack_Horner.jpg|thumb|right|100px|[[Jack Horner (paleontologist)|Horner]]]] [[File:Steve_Jobs_with_red_shawl_edit2.jpg|thumb|right|100px|[[Steve Jobs|Jobs]]]] [[File:Rebecca_Kamen_FF2011-02-04_crop.jpg|thumb|right|100px|[[Rebecca Kamen|Kamen]]]] [[Image:Leonardo da Vinci - presumed self-portrait - WGA12798.jpg|thumb|right|100px|[[Leonardo da Vinci]]]] [[Image:James Clerk Maxwell.png|right|thumb|100 px|[[James Clerk Maxwell|Maxwell]]]] [[Image:Lorin Morgan-Richards in Cardiff, Wales.jpg|right|thumb|100 px|[[Lorin Morgan-Richards|Morgan-Richards]]]] [[Image:Hal Prewitt on Podium 2015.jpg|thumb|right|100px|[[Hal Prewitt|Prewitt]]]] [[File:Tesla circa 1890.jpeg|right|thumb|100 px|[[Nikola Tesla|Tesla]]]] [[File:Bella Thorne March 18, 2014 (cropped).jpg|right|thumb|100 px|[[Bella Thorne|Thorne]]]]
* [[Sam Allardyce]], English footballer and football manager<ref>{{Citation|last=Allardyce|first=Sam|title=Big Sam: My Autobiography|publisher=[[Headline Publishing Group|Headline]]|year=2015|isbn=978-1-4722-3267-0}}</ref> * [[Anthony Andrews]], English actor<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bdadyslexia.org.uk/about-dyslexia/famous-dyslexics.html |title=The British Dyslexia Association – Famous Dyslexics |accessdate=28 January 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714004805/http://www.bdadyslexia.org.uk/about-dyslexia/famous-dyslexics.html |archivedate=14 July 2014 |df= }}</ref> * [[Jennifer Aniston]], American actress<ref>title=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/jennifer-aniston-reveals-struggles-dyslexia-764854</ref> * [[Louise Arnold]], English author<ref>{{cite news | last = Oakes | first = Keily | title = BBC winner realises writing dream | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/arts/4672991.stm | publisher = news.bbc.co.uk | date = 13 July 2005 | accessdate = 30 December 2008 }}</ref> * [[Michael "Atters" Attree]], English satirical writer and comedian<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.festivalpreviews.com/blog/page/4.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-05-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101110090552/http://www.festivalpreviews.com/blog/page/4.html |archivedate=10 November 2010 |df= }} 2010 Brighton Fringe Festival: Atters Interview (Question 8, number 4)</ref> * [[Abhishek Bachchan]], Indian [[Bollywood]] actor<ref>{{cite news|title=Times of India|work=Aamir praises Abhishek|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/Entertainment/India_Buzz/Aamir_praises_Abhishek/articleshow/2631936.cms | date=19 December 2007}}</ref> * [[Geoff Barrow]], English musician<ref>{{cite news|last=Gieben|first=Bram|title=Geoff Barrow talks DROKK: "2000AD is as important to me as Public Enemy"|url=http://www.theskinny.co.uk/music/features/301804-geoff_barrow_talks_drokk_2000ad_as_important_me_public_enemy|accessdate=6 May 2012|newspaper=The Skinny|date=2 May 2012}}</ref> * [[Princess Beatrice of York]], member of the [[British Royal Family]] and seventh in [[line of succession to the British throne]]<ref>{{cite news|last=Bannerman|first=Lucy|title=Duchess tells of Beatrice's long struggle with dyslexia: Princess 'now catching up with her peers'|newspaper=The Herald|date=23 March 2005|page=5}}</ref> * [[Alexander Graham Bell]], American inventor and scientist<ref name="Elsie Jones-Smith 2011 135">{{cite book|title=Spotlighting the Strengths of Every Single Student: Why U.S. Schools Need a New, Strengths-Based Approach: Why U.S. Schools Need a New, Strengths-Based Approach|year=2011|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=9780313391545|page=135|author=Elsie Jones-Smith|quote=Some notable famous people who have been diagnosed with dyslexia include: Alexander Graham Bell, inventor of the telephone; Albert Einstein, creator of the theory of relativity; Pierre Curie, physicist and 1903 Nobel Prize winner...}}</ref><ref name="happydyslexic.com">[http://www.happydyslexic.com/node/15 Famous people with dyslexia: Inventors & scientists]</ref> * [[Michael Bennet]], American politician; [[United States Senate|United States Senator]] from Colorado<ref>{{cite news | first=Nancy | last=Mitchell |title=One finalist enough for DPS board | date=9 January 2009 | url=http://www.rockymountainnews.com/news/2009/jan/09/one-finalist-enough-for-dps-board | work=Rocky Mountain News | accessdate=25 April 2009}}</ref> * [[Robert Benton]], American screenwriter and film director<ref>{{cite news|title=His love of lit led director to Roth tale|newspaper=Philadelphia Inquirer|date=2 November 2003|page=H09}}</ref> * [[Orlando Bloom]], English actor<ref name="files">{{cite web | title=The Orlando Bloom Files | work=Learning Disability | url=http://www.theorlandobloomfiles.com/articles/j1404march.html | accessdate=1 July 2006 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070603094801/http://www.theorlandobloomfiles.com/articles/j1404march.html | archive-date=3 June 2007 | dead-url=yes | df=dmy-all }}</ref> * [[David Boies]], American attorney<ref>http://archive.fortune.com/magazines/fortune/fortune_archive/2002/05/13/322876/index.htm</ref> * [[Roberto Bolaño]], Chilean novelist and poet<ref>{{Cite journal | last=Kerr | first=Sarah | title=The Triumph of Roberto Bolaño | journal=The New York Review of Books | date=18 December 2008 | url=http://www.nybooks.com/articles/archives/2008/dec/18/the-triumph-of-roberto-bolano/ | postscript=<!-- Bot inserted parameter. Either remove it; or change its value to "." for the cite to end in a ".", as necessary. -->{{inconsistent citations}}}}</ref> * [[Jeremy Bonderman]], American baseball player<ref>{{cite web|title=Detroit Free Press |work=FAMILY, FORDS AND FASTBALLS: Tigers starter Jeremy Bonderman stays true to small-town, blue-jeans roots |url=http://www.freep.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20060507/SPORTS02/605070680/1050 |accessdate=1 July 2006 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070926231526/http://www.freep.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=%2F20060507%2FSPORTS02%2F605070680%2F1050 |archivedate=26 September 2007 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> * [[Chaz Bono]], American advocate, writer, musician and actor (see reference for Cher below) * [[Lara Flynn Boyle]], American actress<ref>{{cite news|title=At Home With: Lara Flynn Boyle; Tough Cookie, Snug Retreat|work=The New York Times|author=Jamie Diamond|date=27 June 2002|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2002/06/27/garden/at-home-with-lara-flynn-boyle-tough-cookie-snug-retreat.html|accessdate=25 April 2013}}</ref> * [[Richard Branson]], English entrepreneur<ref>{{cite book | last=Branson | first=Richard | year=1999 | title=Losing My Virginity: How I've Survived, Had Fun, and Made a Fortune Doing Business My Way | chapter=A family that would have killed for each other. 1950 – 1963 | edition=1st | url=http://www.virgin.com/aboutus/autobiography/ | publisher=Three Rivers Press | location= | accessdate=30 August 2006 | isbn=0-8129-3229-3 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060830003417/http://www.virgin.com/aboutus/autobiography/ | archivedate=30 August 2006 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> *[[Chrisann Brennan]], an American Artist and the author of ''[[The Bite in the Apple]]''<ref name="bite">{{cite book |last=Brennan |first=Chrisann |date= |title=[[The Bite in the Apple|THE BITE IN THE APPLE:A Memoir of My Life with Steve Jobs]] |url= |location= |publisher=St. Martin's Griffin |page=ebook |isbn= |accessdate= }}</ref> * [[Marcus Brigstocke]], English comedian and satirist<ref>{{cite news|title=The funny side to dyslexia|work=The Guardian|author=Matt Keating|date=6 November 2007|url=https://www.theguardian.com/education/2007/nov/06/burlesque.news?gusrc=rss&feed=global | location=London}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Room 101 – Marcus Brigstocke Grammar Bullies|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lm2OzAX86JU|accessdate=7 August 2007 }}</ref> * [[Erin Brockovich]], American legal clerk, socio-environmental activist<ref>{{cite news | first = Adele | last = Slaughter | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Erin Brockovich scripts victory over dyslexia | url = https://www.usatoday.com/news/health/spotlight/2001-05-22-brockovich-dyslexia.htm | work = USA Today | date = 22 May 2001 | accessdate = 25 August 2008}}</ref> * [[Max Brooks]], American author and screenwriter; son of actress [[Anne Bancroft]] and director [[Mel Brooks]]<ref name="Yale">{{cite web | url=http://dyslexia.yale.edu/maxbrooks.html | title=Max Brooks, Author * The Yale Center for Dyslexia & Creativity | accessdate=29 March 2016 | author=Glader, Sue}}</ref> * [[Fred Brophy]], Australian tent boxing promoter * [[Neil Bush]], American businessman and son of [[George H. W. Bush]]<ref>{{cite news|title=Neil Bush, Perplexed, Angry at Attention He's Received|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=YEhSAAAAIBAJ&sjid=fDYNAAAAIBAJ&dq=neil%20bush%20dyslexia&pg=5312%2C2759234|accessdate=6 May 2012|newspaper=The Victoria Advocate|date=15 July 1990|agency=Associated Press}}</ref> * [[Octavia Butler]], American science fiction author<ref>{{cite news|title=Obituary (The Guardian)|url=https://www.theguardian.com/news/2006/mar/16/guardianobituaries.bookscomment| accessdate=25 July 2008 | location=London | date=16 March 2006 | first=Kodwo | last=Eshun}}</ref> * [[Celine Byrne]], Irish soprano<ref>{{cite web|first=Hillary|last=Fennell|url=http://www.irishexaminer.com/lifestyle/features/interviews/this-much-i-know-celine-byrne-219899.html|title=This much I know: Celine Byrne|work=[[Irish Examiner]]|date=30 January 2013|quote=People might be interested to know that I'm dyslexic.}}</ref> * [[Stephen J. Cannell]], American creator of shows such as ''[[The A-Team]]''<ref name="dudikoff">{{cite web|title=Cannell Helps "Cobra" Star Find Ways Around Dyslexia|url=http://www.dudikoff.de/english/artikel03.htm| accessdate=9 October 2006}}</ref> * [[Carl XVI Gustaf of Sweden|Carl XVI Gustaf]], King of [[Sweden]]<ref>"A time to rejoice: Sweden's King Carl XVI Gustaf at 50" by Michael Jagerblom in ''Scandinavian Review'', autumn 1996 {{cite web|url=http://www.findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qa3760/is_199610/ai_n8750692 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2006-07-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050301092845/http://www.findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qa3760/is_199610/ai_n8750692 |archivedate= 1 March 2005 |df= }}</ref> * [[Prince Carl Philip, Duke of Värmland|Carl Philip of Sweden]], Prince of Sweden<ref>http://www.ibtimes.com/prince-carl-philip-sweden-talks-being-dyslexic-his-struggle-reading-writing-2229464</ref> * [[Lewis Carroll]], English writer and mathematician<ref name="Joseph Giovannoli 2000 26">{{cite book|title=The Biology of Belief: How Our Biology Biases Our Beliefs and Perceptions|year=2000|publisher=Rosetta Press, Inc.|isbn=9780970813718|page=26|author=Joseph Giovannoli}}</ref> * [[Dan Carter (Canadian politician)|Dan Carter]], Canadian politician<ref name=carter>[https://www.cbc.ca/radio/asithappens/as-it-happens-tuesday-edition-1.4874731/how-oshawa-s-new-mayor-recovered-from-addiction-and-got-off-the-streets-1.4874735 "How Oshawa's new mayor recovered from addiction and got off the streets"]. page.title: List of state visits received by King Felipe VI of Spain

revision.text:
Since acceding to the throne of [[Spain]] in 2014, [[Felipe VI of Spain|King Felipe VI]] has received a number of [[State visit|state and official visits]]. He usually hosts one or two visiting heads of state each year. ==List of visits== {| class="wikitable sortable" border="1" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto" |- !No. !class="unsortable" | Date !Country !Regime !class="unsortable" | Guests |- !colspan=5|2010s |- | 1 | 29–30 October 2014 | {{flag|Chile}} | [[Republic]] | President [[Michelle Bachelet]]{{Cite web|url=http://www.casareal.es/ES/Actividades/Paginas/actividades_actividades_detalle.aspx?data=12172|title=Casa de Su Majestad el Rey de España - Actividades y Agenda - Visita de Estado de Su Excelencia la Presidenta de la República de Chile, Sra. Michelle Bachelet Jeria|website=www.casareal.es|language=es|access-date=2018-04-16}} |- | 2 | 1–3 March 2015 | {{flag|Colombia}} | [[Republic]] | President [[Juan Manuel Santos]]

'''Maria Aleksandrovna Petrova '''(born May 15, 1978),<ref>[http://www.serial-killers.ru/ugolovno-processualnye-akty/opredelenie-verxovnogo-suda-po-delu-petrovoj-ma.htm Определение Верховного Суда РФ по делу Петровой М. А.]</ref> known as the "[[Zyuzino District|Zyuzino]] Maniac", is a [[Russia]]n [[spree killer]] who killed two men and attempted to kill others. Her crimes, to some extent, are unique in the criminal history of Russia.<ref>''[//ru.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D0%98%D0%BB%D1%8C%D1%87%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%BA%D0%BE,_%D0%9E%D0%BA%D1%81%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%B0_%D0%AE%D1%80%D1%8C%D0%B5%D0%B2%D0%BD%D0%B0 Ильченко О. Ю.]'' [http://cyberleninka.ru/article/n/biologicheskie-teorii-o-prestupnoy-aktivnosti-zhenschin Биологические теории о преступной активности женщин] // Криминология: вчера, сегодня, завтра. 2013, № 4 (31). — C. 41.</ref>
== Biography == Maria Petrova enjoyed [[Swimming (sport)|swimming]] since childhood, but was uncommunicative and withdrawn. Once, according to her own statements, she was raped. The rapist, according to Petrova, was a young man. After that, as she claimed, she was molested by an elderly colleague at work, and developed a deep hatred for men.<ref name="петрова">{{Cite web|url=http://www.serial-killers.ru/karts/petrova.htm|title=Петрова, Мария|last=Саша.|website=Serial-Killers.ru]|archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/67IJoctoY|archive-date=2012-04-30|access-date=2010-06-12}}</ref>
She taught physical education at the Moscow Electron-Technological College, showing the following characteristics:{{Cquote | quote = ... During her work, she showed herself as a disciplined, conscientious and hard-working teacher. In addition to training sessions in physical culture, she created and organized the work of a sports section in weight-lifting. M. Petrova continues to actively engage in sports - swimming...<ref name="дд">{{cite web|author=[[Микеладзе, Вахтанг Евгеньевич|Вахтанг Микеладзе]]|year=2002|url=http://video.yandex.ru/users/gd751/view/161/|title=Документальный фильм из цикла "Документальный детектив" — "Вооружена и очень опасна"|publisher=Телекомпания «Останкино»|accessdate=2010-06-20|language=|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/67IJpH9hD|archivedate=2012-04-30}}</ref>}}Petrova also had a degree in psychoneurology. She had a masculine appearance: a muscular figure, broad shoulders and was pretty tall.
On March 1, 2002, Petrova killed 20-year-old Sergei Makariev by stabbing him twice with a knife. Subsequently, she explained that he harassed her, but no witnesses confirmed this. The murder took place at the bus stop of the Shalom Theater, near [[Varshavskaya (Moscow Metro)|Varshavskaya Metro Station]]. On March 27, Petrova killed a 60-year-old pensioner, Nikolai Zhabin, by cutting his throat. Subsequently, Petrova committed three more attempted murders (all victims survived), and was suspected of another attack, but was not charged due to lack of evidence. All attacks were carried out in the same way - stab wounds to the peritoneum and neck.
Petrova was not afraid of being caught, as she committed her crimes in front of dozens of people. Having a sufficiently public profession as a teacher and committing crimes in one area, she was soon exposed and arrested on April 23, 2002. Petrova soon confessed to everything. She was charged with killing two and attempting to kill four more people. The forensic psychiatric examination recognized her as [[Insanity defense|insane]] and sent her for [[compulsory treatment]].

Maniacs go free]" Echo of Moscow, January 28, 2013 * ''Maskakova E. ''"[http://bloknot.ru/obshhestvo/nazvany-samy-e-zhestokie-zhenshhiny-ubijtsy-rossii-275911.html The most cruel women killers of Russia are named]" Bloknot.ru, July 30, 2015 * ''Prikhodko S. ''"[http://www.allkriminal.ru/article/4154/436 The Mystery of the Zyuzino Maniac..]" Kriminal.rf, 2006, No. 32 (436)
